Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>superior</kanji> and <kanji>elegant</kanji> has much <vocabulary>elegance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grace</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She is a self-appointed "elegant madam."
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は自称「優雅なマダム」です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>invade</kanji> and <kanji>enter</kanji> that is an <vocabulary>intrusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This computer virus is going to penetrate thousands of computers at the stroke of midnight on the night of New Year’s Eve.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このコンピュータウィルスは、大晦日の夜に時計の針が12時を告げると、何千台ものパソコンに侵入をするんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wood</kanji> <kanji>skin</kanji> is <vocabulary>tree bark</vocabulary>. It's the wooden skin around trees.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is the bark edible?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その樹皮は食べられますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you do a <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> of something it's like you're <kanji>revolv</kanji>ing back to how things originally were. This is a <vocabulary>withdrawal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>repeal</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>taking back</vocabulary> something you said previously.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened <jp>てつ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Sorry, I take back what I said.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ごめん。前言撤回するよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm in trouble because the manager is asking me to withdraw my resignation.
Context 2-JP: <jp>部長から辞表の撤回を求められて困っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I got a LINE message about the repeal of the strike.
Context 3-JP: <jp>スト撤回の知らせがラインで回ってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>意識</jp> is <kanji>consciously</kanji>, then what <kanji>exist</kanji>s <kanji>conceal</kanji>ed in your mind is your <vocabulary>subconscious</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Dreams are often said to reflect our subconscious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夢ってのは、僕たちの潜在意識を反映しているとよく言われるよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is talk that's only inside between us. It's <vocabulary>confidential talk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of <jp>内緒</jp> and kun'yomi of <jp>話</jp>, only rendakued.
Context 1-EN: They are trying to whisper to each other, but their voices are so loud that I can hear everything.
Context 1-JP: <jp>当人達は内緒話をしているつもりのようだが、声がでかいので全部筒抜けだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>swamp</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>marsh</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary>, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the <reading>Sho</reading>gun (<jp>しょう</jp>) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.
Context 1-EN: This plant with yellow flowers lives in swamps.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この黄色い花を咲かせる植物は、沼沢地に生息します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mineral</kanji> <kanji>mountain</kanji> is one that you should build <vocabulary>a mine</vocabulary> in, to get all those minerals.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: When I worked in a mine, I always had back pain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鉱山で働いてる時は、いつも背中に痛みがありました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an attack you don't expect. This is a <vocabulary>surprise attack</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We didn’t expect our rival’s surprise attack.
Context 1-JP: <jp>敵の奇襲を予想できなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>news</kanji> report is going to be one full of <vocabulary>good news</vocabulary>. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m here to tell you some good news.
Context 1-JP: <jp>朗報を伝えるためにここに来ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something's got <kanji>charm</kanji> and is to your <kanji>taste</kanji>, then it's your <vocabulary>hobby</vocabulary>. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My hobby is housecleaning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の趣味は家の大掃除です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>紛らす</jp> means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word <vocabulary>to be diverted</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be distracted</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>紛らす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The fever medicine slipped in with other pills and I’m not sure which one is which.
Context 1-JP: <jp>解熱剤が他の薬に紛れちゃってて、どれがどれだか分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I have <kanji>sincerity</kanji> about my <kanji>loyalty</kanji>. That shows <vocabulary>loyalty</vocabulary>, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Looking back, Hachiko was a dog that had absolute loyalty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今振り返ってみると、ハチ公は絶対的な忠誠心を持ったいい犬だったよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Humanity</kanji> and <kanji>righteousness</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>humanity and justice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There is no honor among thieves.
Context 1-JP: <jp>盗人には仁義はない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: <vocabulary>curse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The witch put a curse on the princess that made it so she could only hold cups upside down.
Context 1-JP: <jp>魔女はお姫様に、コップを逆さまにしか持てなくする呪いをかけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Milord</kanji> (you say very formally with a <kanji>formal name title</kanji>). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Feudal Lords were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My toe?! NO!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.
Context 1-EN: I drew a handsome feudal lord to waste time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>暇つぶしにイケメンの殿様の絵を描きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>mourning</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> is your <vocabulary>mourning dress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mourning clothes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the on'yomi for <jp>服</jp> and the kun'yomi for <jp>喪</jp>, which you learned with the word <jp>喪</jp>. You should know how to read this word!
Context 1-EN: My sister is anorexic and when wearing her mourning dress, she looked even skinnier.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の妹は拒食症なのですが、喪服を着ているとより一層痩せ細ってみえました。</jp>

Meaning: To Hang,To Depend On,To Be At Stake
Meaning Mnemonic: If something is <kanji>suspend</kanji>ed, it is going <vocabulary>to hang</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary> your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
Reading Mnemonic: We're depending on you to help us to get this <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>), okay?
Context 1-EN: I’m worried if he is okay.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の安否が気に懸かります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lawn</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>turf</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!
Context 1-EN: The turf in these turf cookies gives them their green color.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この芝草が、芝草クッキーを緑色にしてくれるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>hinge</kanji> is the <vocabulary>center</vocabulary> <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> point.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How could it stimulate her central nervous system?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてそれが彼女の中枢神経系を刺激したの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Hey Koichi, we’ve got a lot to catch up on.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やあ、コウイチ！俺、久しぶりにお前に会ったから、話したいことが山ほどあるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally, a cylinder is a <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary>s, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a <reading>two two</reading> (<jp>つつ</jp>) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.
Context 1-EN: Can you put the thermometer back in its tube when you’re done using it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>使い終わったら、体温計を筒の中に戻しておいてね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something has a <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>edge</kanji>, it's probably <vocabulary>unrelated</vocabulary> to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This country road is free from traffic jams.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この田舎道は、渋滞とは無縁です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rob</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rob</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Her mother told her that their puppy's life was stolen by an evil spirit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母親は、少女に、悪霊が犬の命を奪ったのだと教えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>praise</kanji> you for what you did, so here's your <kanji>prize</kanji> to go along with my praise, a <vocabulary>medal</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When she tried to go up on the stage to get her prize, she tripped on the stairs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>褒賞を受け取るために舞台に上がろうとした時、彼女は階段につまづきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> (often associated with atoms and nuclear tech) <kanji>conceal</kanji>ing machine is the <vocabulary>nuclear submarine</vocabulary>. It is nuclear, and it conceals itself.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Nuclear submarines are sometimes called Gensen, for short.
Context 1-JP: <jp>原子力潜水艦は、略して原潜と呼ばれることもある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>best regards</kanji> and this can be <vocabulary>best regards</vocabulary> as well. It can also mean <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>suitably</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Please say thank you to your mother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お母様に宜しくお伝えくださいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>untie</kanji> the <kanji>analysis</kanji>, you are really just doing <vocabulary>analysis</vocabulary> to the analysis, if you catch my drift.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I analyzed it while dancing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は踊りながらそれを解析してみました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>stone</kanji> <kanji>hedge</kanji> is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a <vocabulary>stone wall</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings for <jp>石</jp> and <jp>垣</jp> combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.
Context 1-EN: He couldn’t climb over the stone wall because he has artificial legs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は義足を付けていたので、石垣を乗り越えられませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rice plant</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rice field</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rice paddy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>いな</jp> reading for <jp>稲</jp> and the regular <jp>田</jp> reading rendaku'd.
Context 1-EN: My friend has much bigger rice fields.
Context 1-JP: <jp>友達はもっと大きい稲田をもっていますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: All the <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>neighbor</kanji>s are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: President Koichi never ignored relationships with neighboring countries.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ大統領は、近隣諸国との関係をないがしろにはしなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that <kanji>chafe</kanji> and <kanji>grate</kanji> have lots of <vocabulary>friction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Does friction cause static electricity?
Context 1-JP: <jp>摩擦によって静電気が生じるんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> then you are doing <vocabulary>rice cultivation</vocabulary>, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>いな</jp> reading with the regular <jp>作</jp> on'yomi reading.
Context 1-EN: He is immersing himself in rice cultivation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は稲作に没頭しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You'll have to imagine a <vocabulary>pillar</vocabulary> standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a <reading>hash-ra</reading> (<jp>はしら</jp>) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.
Context 1-EN: While shopping in the grocery store, I tether my dog to a pole and he always waits for me obediently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのスーパーで買い物をしてる間、私は犬を柱に繋ぐんですが、いつもちゃんと大人しく待ってますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> is an <vocabulary>instant death</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He tried to ride tidal bore and surf it, but unfortunately he died instantly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は潮津波に乗ってサーフィンをしようとしたが、残念ながら即死した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>逃す</jp> is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your <kanji>see</kanji>ing, then you are going <vocabulary>to overlook</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>見</jp> and <jp>逃す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I hadn’t noticed that there was a loophole in the law until now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その法律に抜け穴があることを今の今まで見逃していました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned that <jp>逃げる</jp> means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means <vocabulary>to miss</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary> a good chance, or <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of a good opportunity.
Reading Mnemonic:
Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word:

You missed a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was no gas (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.
Context 1-EN: I'll never miss a chance to fall in love!
Context 1-JP: <jp>恋愛のチャンスは逃さないよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: I missed the perfect shot when my husband sneezed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>主人がクシャミをしたので、シャッターチャンスを逃してしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was out of it and missed the announcement.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ボーっとしていて、アナウンスを聞き逃してしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>celebrate</kanji> <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is a <vocabulary>celebration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that <jp>祝</jp> is read as <jp>しゅう</jp> for this one and you'll be fine.
Context 1-EN: I wrote "congratulations" and my name on the front of the envelope and the amount of money on the back.
Context 1-JP: <jp>封筒の表には「御祝儀」と自分の名前を、裏には金額を書いたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Unite</kanji> something together and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it and you have <vocabulary>unification</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>generalization</vocabulary>. Nowadays this word is used to mean <vocabulary>management</vocabulary> in some contexts too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My father is responsible for unifying 100 subordinates at his company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は会社では100人の部下を統括する責任者です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is that guy the new general manager?
Context 2-JP: <jp>新しく入った統括マネージャーってあいつのこと？</jp>
Context 3-EN: We always disagree with the people in Risk Management.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺たちはいつもリスク統括部の奴らとは意見が合わないんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Humility</kanji> is <kanji>heavy</kanji>, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be <vocabulary>discreet</vocabulary> instead.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember the alternative reading for <jp>重</jp>. If you aren't discreet or careful, the evil Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<jp>ちょう</jp>)will find you and kill you!
Context 1-EN: What makes you so careful?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてそんなに慎重なんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>緩む</jp> is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning <vocabulary>to loosen</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>緩む</jp>, so you can use that!
Context 1-EN: Please feel free to loosen the necktie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうぞネクタイをお緩めになってください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>いね</jp> reading of this kanji. You can think of it like you're saying "<jp>いいね</jp>!" at the rice plant you're looking at (just shorten the <jp>い</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Tofugu is suspending publication because all Tofugu members are busy harvesting rice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguメンバーはみんな稲刈りで忙しいので、Tofuguのブログは休刊中です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>range</kanji> is <kanji>outside</kanji> of the range, meaning you're <vocabulary>out of range</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Oh no. My brother said that he’d call me on my cell, but there’s no reception here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しまった！兄ちゃんが俺の携帯に電話するって言ってたのに、ここ圏外だわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fellow countryman</vocabulary> (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a <vocabulary>Japanese national</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How many Japanese residents are there in the United States?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカには在留邦人はどのくらいいるんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>instant</kanji>ly <kanji>effect</kanji>ive! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means <vocabulary>immediate effect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant effect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.
Context 1-EN: I’ll show you a way to instantly remove eye strain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>即効で目の疲れを取る方法をお教えしましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>warship</kanji> <kanji>squad</kanji> is a <vocabulary>naval fleet</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>armada</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I expected stronger resistance from the enemy’s naval fleet, so I’m kind of disappointed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>敵の艦隊からもっと激しい抵抗があると思っていたので、なんだか拍子抜けです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where you go play go. It's a <vocabulary>go parlor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>go playing parlor</vocabulary>.
Reading Whitelist: ごかいしょ,ごかいじょ
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I caught him peeping into our Go parlor this morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝俺たちの碁会所を覗き見していた男を取っ捕まえてやったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>leap</kanji> is what you do when you do a lot of <vocabulary>activities</vocabulary> and making <vocabulary>great efforts</vocabulary> to do them. It's no normal leap, it's a lively one, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In the relay race, he beat five runners in a row and his team won first place.
Context 1-JP: <jp>リレーのレースで、彼は五人をごぼう抜きにする活躍をみせ、彼のチームは見事一等賞に輝いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tariff</kanji> of the <kanji>world</kanji> is a <vocabulary>concession</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>settlement</vocabulary>. That's just how the world works.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you want to know about the history of the Shanghai French Concession, he knows a lot about that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昔の上海とフランス租界について知りたいのなら、彼がそれについては詳しいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blow</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to blow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Be patient and don’t give up. Tomorrow’s wind will blow tomorrow!
Context 1-JP: <jp>我慢するんだ！諦めるなよ。明日は明日の風が吹くんだからさ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What's the first two letters of the word mourning? It's mo (も). You can use that to remember.
Context 1-EN: I’m very sorry but I’m afraid I can’t send a New Year’s card because I’m in mourning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大変申し訳ありませんが、喪に服しているため年賀状が送れないのです。</jp>

Meaning: Cutting Edge,Up-And-Coming,State Of The Art,Freshly Picked
Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>new</kanji> and <kanji>sharp</kanji> (presumably because it's so new) is on the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>up-and-coming</vocabulary>, the next big thing!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The company decided to buy the cutting edge computer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その会社は最新鋭のパソコンを購入することを決定しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, <jp>ぬま</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I guess I have to jump into the swamp anyway.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どっちにしろ沼に飛び込まなきゃいけないと思うしね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>揺る</jp> which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it <vocabulary>to be shaken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be jolted</vocabulary>. You know this because it's really <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) for you to be shaken like this.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>揺る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: You were looking at her bouncing boobs, weren’t you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今あの子のおっぱいがボインボイン揺れてるのを見てたよね？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>iron</kanji> <kanji>mineral</kanji> is <vocabulary>iron ore</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I mined a bunch of iron ore in Minecraft.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マイクラでたくさん鉄鉱石を採掘した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hinge</kanji> <kanji>axis</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>axle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary>. It's the axis where things hinge.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "Guruguru-bat" is a game where you compete on how fast you can get to the goal after spinning around a bat with your forehead on the end of the bat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ぐるぐるバット」は、おでこをバットの先に付けて、そのバットを枢軸としてぐるぐる回転した後に、誰が目的地まで速く辿り着けるかを競う遊びです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dig</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you are going <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary> you are going to end up making a <reading>ho</reading>le (<jp>ほ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Kumaman is a middle-aged, widower living and digging gold like his father before him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クママンは中年の男やもめで、家業で金を掘っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Presents</kanji> that you give as a <kanji>bribe</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>bribery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This may be called a "present" in some countries, but in this country it's "bribery."
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、ある国では「プレゼント」と呼ばれるかもしれないが、この国では「贈賄」である。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>famous</kanji> <kanji>honor</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>, but it is also a <vocabulary>prestige</vocabulary> to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He says he has no interest in gaining prestige, but I think that’s a lie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは名誉を得ることには興味がないなんて言ってるけど、俺は嘘だと思うね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>alone</kanji> <kanji>chant</kanji> is one you do alone. It's a <vocabulary>solo</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Even though I have hay fever, I have to do a solo in the recital.
Context 1-JP: <jp>花粉症なのに、発表会で独唱しなくちゃいけないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>distance</kanji> that is <kanji>detach</kanji>ed from the distance is the <vocabulary>distance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>range</vocabulary>. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Long‐distance flights will be tough for me when I get old.
Context 1-JP: <jp>年を取ったら長距離のフライトはきつくなるだろうね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>reverse</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Pac-Man counterattacked and started eating the monsters that were chasing him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>パックマンは、追ってくるモンスターを逆襲して食べ始めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>warship</kanji> is a <vocabulary>battleship</vocabulary>. Did you sink it? Oh oh! You sunk my <jp>軍艦</jp>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to open a specialty shop for plastic battleship models.
Context 1-JP: <jp>軍艦プラモの専門店を開く予定なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>埋める</jp> is "to bury." This verb is <vocabulary>to get buried</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be buried</vocabulary>. You know this because it's <reading>more rare</reading> (<jp>もれる</jp>) to get buried than it is for you to bury someone else. Really you can only get buried once, to be honest, because you're probably going to die.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>埋める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The snow piled up 30 centimeters deep last night and my car got buried.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜、雪が30cmも積もり、車が埋もれてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>patrol</kanji> and <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the block to make your <vocabulary>patrol</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>going around</vocabulary> patrolling.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The weather forecast was wrong and it started to rain while I was on patrol.
Context 1-JP: <jp>天気予報が外れて、巡回中に雨が降り出しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>seize</kanji> and <kanji>acquire</kanji> you're making an <vocabulary>acquisition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>possession</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you play the game today, you can get double the usual amount of coins.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日ゲームをプレイすると、いつもの二倍のコインが獲得できるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: At the <kanji>arrival</kanji> time you will <kanji>arrive</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>arrival</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was too hyper when I arrived in Japan, wasn’t I?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本に到着した時、私はちょっとテンションが高すぎましたよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Zero</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> is <vocabulary>below zero</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Sub zero</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It doesn’t matter if it’s ten or twenty below zero, we do our wash here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>零下十度だろうが二十度だろうがに関係なく、洗い物はここでします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tariff</kanji> <kanji>tax</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>taxes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>taxation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is there a specific tax for rice paddies?
Context 1-JP: <jp>田んぼには特定の租税が課されているんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
It's a bubble!

A Wha---? (あわ)

A BUBBLE.

A WHA???
Context 1-EN: The moment he took a puff of marijuana, he fell to the ground foaming at the mouth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マリファナを一服した瞬間、男は口から泡を吹いて地面に倒れ込んだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Energy</kanji> <kanji>bubbles</kanji> are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an <vocabulary>air bubble</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The first thing we have to do is remove the air bubbles from the pottery clay.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一番最初にしなくちゃいけないことが、陶芸用の粘土から気泡を取り除くことです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>bubbles</kanji> are bubbles that come from the water. This is usually in the form of <vocabulary>foam</vocabulary>, but could also be a <vocabulary>bubble</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My browser crashed before I saved my data so my efforts to write a long message ended in failure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>データを保存する前にブラウザがクラッシュしてしまったため、長文のメッセージを書いていた努力が水泡に帰してしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji itself means <kanji>habit</kanji> but it usually refers to a <vocabulary>bad habit</vocabulary>, so try to remember that meaning if you could.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I’ve fallen into the habit of spraining my fingers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>突き指が癖になってしまっているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>departure</kanji> of <kanji>bubbles</kanji> is when bubbles leave something, like a mouth. That's why this is <vocabulary>foaming</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could you put the styrofoam in this plastic bag? We throw away the rest of the garbage separately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>発泡スチロールはこの袋に入れてもらってもいい？他のゴミとは分別して捨てるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>skin</kanji> under your <kanji>skin</kanji> is still <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary>. The extra layer is there to make sure when you get little cuts they don't bleed all over the place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The skin on my fingertips is thick because I play the guitar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ギターを弾くので指先の皮膚が厚いんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Secluded</kanji> and <kanji>closed</kanji> off, putting you in <vocabulary>confinement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>imprisonment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After becoming a housewife, it’s like I’ve become a war prisoner, confined to the kitchen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>専業主婦になってからというもの、まるで捕虜になって、台所に幽閉されてでもいるかのようだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>habit</kanji> is something you say with your mouth a lot. It's a habit. It's your <vocabulary>favorite phrase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>catchphrase</vocabulary>. Many people have the <vocabulary>habit of saying</vocabulary> the certain things over and over again, whether they want to or not.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of both kanji. <jp>癖</jp> is the reading you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: That chef’s catchphrase is, "Such and such is in season."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「何々が旬の季節です」ってあのシェフの口癖だよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>secluded</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> is someone who's secluded and a ghost, because everyone's forgotten about him (thus the "ghostness" of him). This thing is a <vocabulary>ghost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>specter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "Let’s skip school and go to the arcade today. YOLO!" "I don’t think so. I see ghosts all the time, so I believe in a world after death."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「今日、学校サボってゲーセン行こうぜ。人生は一度っきりだしな！」「そうかな。僕はよく幽霊を見るから、死後の世界を信じてるんだけど。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Forg</kanji>ing and <kanji>tempering</kanji> of things is <vocabulary>tempering</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>forging</vocabulary> of things. When you do this to your body, to get ready for the big race, it's called <vocabulary>training</vocabulary>. (Though body tempering sounds way cooler, don't you think?)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Nobody can get perfect pronunciation overnight. To improve your pronunciation you need continuous and proper training.
Context 1-JP: <jp>発音が一晩で上手くなる人なんていません。発音を上達させるには、継続的かつ正しい鍛錬が必要です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>forge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to forge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to temper</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>To forge</vocabulary> something, you need to have your <reading>kit</reading> (<jp>きた</jp>) with you. Without it, you won't be doing any forging at all.
Context 1-EN: Thanks to the strict training I’ve given him since birth, my son is now called a child prodigy at piano.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生まれたての頃からミッチリ鍛えたおかげで、息子は今ピアノの天才児と呼ばれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>art</kanji> of <kanji>tempering</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>alchemy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The rain poured down outside on the day the alchemist utterly failed at transforming lead into gold.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ある錬金術士が鉛を金に変えようとして失敗した日、外は雨がザザ降りでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a plant or an animal <kanji>die</kanji>s you have to <vocabulary>discard</vocabulary> it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house, that's weird.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The manuscript was rejected the other day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こないだの原稿は没になってしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>head of plant</kanji> of a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> is the <vocabulary>head of rice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ear of rice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Rice is our staple food, but that doesn’t mean all Japanese people have seen beautiful, golden ears of rice bowing in the breeze.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お米は私達の主食ですが、だからといって日本人全員が風に靡く美しい金色の稲穂を見た事がある訳ではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sovereign</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is one that is part of its own <vocabulary>empire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The statute of limitations for murder was abolished in the Tofugu Empire.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofugu帝国では、殺人事件の時効は廃止されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>sovereign</kanji> <kanji>emperor</kanji> of Japan is also the <vocabulary>emperor</vocabulary> of other places too!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The emperor has a weakness for sake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>皇帝はお酒には目がない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: We were so hungry that we gathered ears of wheat and ate them raw.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達はお腹がペコペコだったので、麦の穂を集めてそのまま生で食べたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: "Isn’t it possible that she really isn’t that upset?" "This is just the calm before the storm."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「彼女、もしかして本当は全然怒ってないんじゃない？」「ただの嵐の前の静けさだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the words <jp>背</jp> and <jp>高い</jp> put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a <vocabulary>tall</vocabulary> person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!
Context 1-EN: I’ve never seen such a tall hobbit before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんなに背が高いホビットは見たことがないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sovereign</kanji> <kanji>government</kanji> and <kanji>Politics</kanji> are those who are part of the <vocabulary>imperial government</vocabulary>. This type of government is <vocabulary>imperialism</vocabulary>. Of course, back in the day there weren't as many sovereign governments out there, so imperialism is the one that fits the bill in this word's case.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In the time of the Roman Empire, the emperor was keeping an eye on the village people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ローマ帝政時代、皇帝はその村の人達に目をつけていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>blink</kanji> of <kanji>time</kanji> is a mere <vocabulary>moment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was so impressed with him when he said that at the moment I was going to say it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>言いたかったことを彼が瞬時にズバッと言ってくれたので、とても感心しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>blink</kanji> <kanji>interval of time</kanji> is a very short period of time. It's <vocabulary>an instant</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>moment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The moment they walk into a spider web, people suddenly turn into karate experts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>蜘蛛の巣にぶつかった瞬間に、人は突然空手の達人へと変身する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blink</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to blink</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>Mah ta ta</reading> (<jp>またた</jp>) is showing, causing you <vocabulary>to blink</vocabulary>. I don't know what a "tata" is, but I bet you could come up with something that's blink-worthy.
Context 1-EN: The landscape was covered by snow in a flash and everything turned white.
Context 1-JP: <jp>辺りの景色は瞬く間に雪に覆われ、真っ白になった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>pride</kanji> is too <kanji>big</kanji>. You make it bigger than it is, in fact. You do this with <vocabulary>exaggeration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hyperbole</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I know one in four people think advertising is exaggerated, but I don’t think all advertisements are an exaggeration.
Context 1-JP: <jp>四人に一人が広告は誇張されていると思っていることは知っていますが、私は全部が全部誇大広告ではないと思うんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>blink</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blink</vocabulary> and a <vocabulary>wink</vocabulary> as well, depending on how many eyes you use.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>A wink</vocabulary> is all it takes to get the "<reading>Ma butter</reading>" (<jp>まばた</jp>) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.
Context 1-EN: Don’t blink and just keep looking at the picture please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>瞬きせずに、この絵を見続けてください。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Proud Of,To Boast Of
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pride</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to be proud of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to boast of</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <reading>hoe </reading> (<jp>ほこ</jp>) is the kid who is carrying around a hoe all the time, swinging it around, doing dumb things with it. He's so proud of it, though, and it shows on his face. He's always boasting about his hoe skillz too.
Context 1-EN: This short film is about the robotics industry that Japan boasts of to the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この短編映画では、日本が世界に誇るロボット産業をテーマとしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>blink</kanji> is one instant. That is <vocabulary>an instant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a moment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "You’ll never catch me!" "Gotcha!" "What! That was fast! You caught me in an instant, but that’s childish. You should go a little easier on your kid."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「お前には捕まらないぞ！」「捕まえたっ！」「うわっ！速い！一瞬だったな。でも、大人げないよ。子どもなんだからもう少し手加減してよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>距離</jp> (<kanji>distance</kanji>) that is <kanji>short</kanji> is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Only years later did she finally admit she was the sprinter who won the short distance race.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ほんの数年後、彼女はようやく自分がその短距離走で優勝した短距離走者だったことを認めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>pride</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it out. It's an <vocabulary>exaggeration</vocabulary>, because you've stretched your pride out pretty thin.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The review said that it was the best camera ever, but it was an exaggeration just like I thought.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レビューで今までで最高のカメラだとか何とか書かれてたけど、それはやっぱり誇張だったね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>manor</kanji> <kanji>park</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>manor</vocabulary>. That's what a manor is, though. It's a big house that has an awesome garden/park around it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Everything is in order for the introduction of manorialism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>庄園制度導入への準備は全て整っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>small craft</vocabulary>. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are all ones you've seen before. <jp>小</jp> uses its <jp>こ</jp> reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: The Pacific Ocean was filled with little boats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>太平洋上には小舟がひしめきあっていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be <jp>船</jp>). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as <jp>船</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I destroyed the fishing boat with a hammer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いさり舟をハンマーで叩いて破壊した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>thwart</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to thwart</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hamper</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Someone walks up to you, saying "<reading>habbah</reading> habbah habbah" (kind of like hubbah hubbah). He's trying to flash you or something. So, you go <vocabulary>to thwart</vocabulary> him with your taser.
Context 1-EN: It seems like someone is trying to prevent him from walking his daughter down the aisle today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かが、彼が今日娘さんを連れてバージンロードを歩くのを阻もうとしているようなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Thwart</kanji> and <kanji>damage</kanji> the advancement of something. That's an <vocabulary>obstruction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inhibition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Drinks containing caffeine inhibit sleep.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カフェインを含む飲み物は、睡眠を阻害します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shut up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shut up</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You need to <reading>damn</reading> (<jp>だま</jp>) your mouth shut and shut up.
Context 1-EN: What’s the matter? Why are you so quiet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしたの？どうして黙っているの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!
Context 1-EN: I asked Aya to draw an illustration to offer to the souls of the dead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>死者の霊魂に捧げる為のイラストを描いてほしいとアヤに頼みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: A bunch of <vocabulary>sack</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>straw bag</vocabulary>s are stacked upon each other to make a <reading>tower</reading> (<jp>たわら</jp>). Imagine walking into this sack tower and wonder how it's all held together. Such poor architecture.
Context 1-EN: Tawara-sensei told us that her name means straw bag and that’s why she has a gold straw rice-bag keychain on her bag.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俵先生は、自分の名前が俵なので、あの金の米俵のキーホルダーを鞄に付けていると言っていましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>sink</kanji> down and <kanji>shut up</kanji>. You go into a <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hush</vocabulary>. This tends to be an awkward silence or hush.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There was an awkward silence and I grabbed a salt shaker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>気まずい沈黙の後、私は塩の入った小瓶を掴みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>neck</kanji> of the <kanji>squad</kanji> is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the <vocabulary>head</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary> of a group.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word so it uses the on'yomi readings, which you've learned already. Go you!
Context 1-EN: Who do you think will be the leader of the first-year students?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どいつが新入生の首班を占めることになると思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The noun version of <kanji>cloudy</kanji> is <vocabulary>cloudiness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cloudy weather</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Cloudy days are actually better for photography than bright afternoon sunlight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>実は、眩しい午後の日差しの下よりも、曇りの日の方が写真撮影には適しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: On the <kanji>soil</kanji> we put <kanji>sack</kanji>s in a circle to mark the <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>arena</vocabulary> in sumo. Go look up some pictures of this word in Japanese and you'll see exactly what we mean. Better yet, go see some live sumo!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Someone threw a piece of bread into the sumo arena.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かが土俵にパンの欠片を投げ込みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Let's learn the <jp>わた</jp> reading, though. Just think <reading>what</reading> (<jp>わた</jp>) is cotton? What is it? What does it mean? Ask a lot of "what" questions about cotton to yourself.
Context 1-EN: I love cotton candy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>綿菓子が大好きなんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Where can I buy cotton material for handicrafts?
Context 2-JP: <jp>手芸用の綿はどこで買えますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The cotton is sticking out of this stuffed animal
Context 3-JP: <jp>ヌイグルミから綿がはみ出ている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>shelf</kanji>, once <kanji>establish</kanji>ed, makes up the <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>building</vocabulary> of the building. Just think of a building that's being built. It looks like a little shelf, doesn't it? That's important because this type of construction usually goes over something between two things, like a bridge.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve never built a bridge before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今まで一度も橋梁を架設したことがありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>write</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a shelf with writing on it. That's a <vocabulary>bookshelf</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bookcase</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Wow! My dad has the exact same bookshelf as you. Did you buy it at IKEA?
Context 1-JP: <jp>わっ！うちの父さん、お前のと全く同じ書架を持ってるぜ。お前もIKEAで買ったの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It will <kanji>carry</kanji> or <kanji>bear</kanji> people like a <kanji>shelf</kanji>. This thing that carries people is a <vocabulary>stretcher</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>litter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Their son was in a car accident and was carried to the hospital on a stretcher, but he ended up in a vegetative state.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこ家の息子さん、交通事故に巻き込まれて担架で病院に担ぎ込まれたんだけど、結局植物状態になっちゃったんだって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>眺める</jp> is "to stare at." The noun version is <vocabulary>view</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary>. It's what you're staring at.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>眺める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: After taking a shower, she was staring at the view out her bedroom window for a short while with her hair still damp.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シャワーの後、髪の毛が半乾きのまましばらく部屋の窓からの眺めを見つめていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>湿る</jp> is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it <vocabulary>to moisten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>湿る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Licking your lips to moisten them isn’t good because it can actually dry them out instead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>唇を舐めて湿らせることは、結局その後乾燥させてしまうことになりうるので、あまりいいことではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>smash</kanji> and the verb vocab version of the kanji is <vocabulary>to smash</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to smash</vocabulary> my stuff? That's <reading>coo' </reading> (<jp>くだ</jp>). Whatever you wanna do.
Context 1-EN: I smashed the cookies with a rolling pin until they were broken into small pieces.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クッキーが粉々になるまで、伸ばし棒で叩いて砕きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>疲れる</jp> is "to be exhausted." This is the noun version, which makes it <vocabulary>tiredness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fatigue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>疲れる</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Heavy snow hit my town and I had to shovel it all day yesterday. I’m already worn out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの町が大雪に見舞われて、昨日は一日中雪かきしなきゃいけなかったんだよ。もう疲れてクタクタだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>waterfall</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are <vocabulary>rapids</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: <jp>滝</jp> and <jp>川</jp>. Careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: My grandma told me that it is very dangerous to swim in the rapids.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祖母に、滝川を泳ぐのは危険だと言われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dilute</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dilute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to water down</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>薄い</jp>, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: This miso soup is too salty. Can you water down a little bit?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この味噌汁はしょっぱすぎるよ。もうちょっと薄めてもらってもいいかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>演</jp> is <kanji>performance</kanji> then the verb version of this would be <vocabulary>to perform</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I am very honored to be able to play such an important role.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな大役を演ずることができて、とても光栄です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Smash</kanji>ed <kanji>stone</kanji> is smashed stone. It's <vocabulary>rubble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>broken stone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This road is currently being paved.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この道は現在砕石舗装工事中です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>powder</kanji> I will <kanji>smash</kanji> it! If I do that, it's <vocabulary>pulverization</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>smashing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My cousin fell and got a comminuted fracture in his left kneecap.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の従兄弟は、転んで左足の膝のお皿を粉砕骨折しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is <vocabulary>clay</vocabulary>. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Are you thinking of buying some clay?
Context 1-JP: <jp>粘土を買おうかなと思ってるの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Change</kanji> your face with <kanji>cosmetics</kanji>! This is via <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary> or, of course, <vocabulary>cosmetics</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>化</jp> is a new reading, <jp>け</jp>. To remember this, think about someone putting on <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary>. They finish putting it on, and then you say "<reading>K, show</reading> (<jp>けしょう</jp>) me!"
Context 1-EN: My skin has gotten worse since I gave birth. What was that cosmetic brand you recommended before?
Context 1-JP: <jp>出産後お肌の調子が悪くってさ〜。前に言ってたおススメの化粧品の名前教えてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>purify</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> you are performing <vocabulary>self purification</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This incident will promote the self-purification of the industry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この事件が業界の自浄を促すだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You use your <kanji>lie</kanji> to <kanji>take</kanji> what you want. That's when you <vocabulary>swindle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cheat</vocabulary> someone to get their stuff. How dare you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My money was swindled by a forged title deed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は偽の売買契約書で、お金を詐取されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deceit</kanji>, so when you're doing deceit, you are going <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary> someone.
Reading Mnemonic: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, <reading>as a moo</reading> (<jp>あざむ</jp>)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.
Context 1-EN: Takashi successfully deceived his girlfriend.
Context 1-JP: <jp>孝志は彼女をうまく欺いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're using a <kanji>dull</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> as a <vocabulary>blunt weapon</vocabulary>. It's all you have to hand.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How much do you spend on blunt weapons every month?
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎月の鈍器代はいくらですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: On the day of Tanabata it was foggy in the morning, but it cleared up by noon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>七夕の日、朝は霧がかかっていましたが、お昼には晴れました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>lie</kanji> about your <kanji>title</kanji>, the title which represents who you are, then that is a <vocabulary>misrepresentation</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>false statement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The gardener immediately recognized the misrepresentation of her age but didn’t say anything.
Context 1-JP: <jp>庭師は彼女が年齢を詐称していることにすぐに気がつきましたが、何も言いませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is going to be a really <vocabulary>thick fog</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>black veil</vocabulary> that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>黒い</jp> and <jp>霧</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My home stay father explained the Black Mist Scandal to me at dinner tonight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ホームステイ先のお父さんが、今日の夕飯の際に黒い霧事件について説明をしてくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>devil</kanji> <kanji>art</kanji> is <vocabulary>black magic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sorcery</vocabulary>. The kind of things that devils do.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "Don’t be so picky! You shouldn’t just study black magic, but white magic too!" "Yeah, yeah. You always say that." "One yeah is enough!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「好き嫌いしないの！黒魔術だけじゃなくて白魔術もちゃんと勉強しなさい！」「はいはい。いつも同じこと言ってるよね。」「"はい"は一回でしょ！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>willow</kanji> for some reason is a <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He’s a famous author of red-light district novels.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は花柳小説の有名な著者ですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The <kanji>willow</kanji> you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's <reading>yah naggy</reading> <vocabulary>weeping willow</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I like the willow design on that Izakaya restaurant’s curtain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの居酒屋の柳模様の暖簾が好きなのよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Morning</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is <vocabulary>morning fog</vocabulary>, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: At a charity auction I made a successful bid on an incredibly beautiful painting of mountains breaking through the morning fog.
Context 1-JP: <jp>チャリティーオークションで、朝霧から山々が浮き出ている素晴らしく美しい絵を落札しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place with <kanji>Italy</kanji> <kanji>force</kanji> is a place known as <vocabulary>Ise</vocabulary>. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the <jp>せ</jp>, not the <jp>せい</jp> you're used to seeing.
Context 1-EN: You should go see the Ise Shrine once.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伊勢神宮には、一度行ってみた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A river of willows... so hilarious! What a great comic haiku, that one is. Try to think of a comic haiku about the river willow, if you can.

The River Willow Flows upstream like a salmon This is not funny
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji <jp>川</jp> doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a <vocabulary>comic haiku</vocabulary>, think of something hilarious... like a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<jp>せん</jp>), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.
Context 1-EN: Could you write your senryu here?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここにあなたの川柳を書いてもらえませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>scroll</kanji> of <kanji>shaku</kanji>. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A <vocabulary>tape measure</vocabulary>!

You can't help but ask them, "<reading>Why</reading> (<jp>わい</jp>) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a book illustration, think of an illustration of a sash. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes.

絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.
