Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The train conductor apologized to the passengers for keeping them waiting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車掌は、乗客たちを待たせていることについて、お詫びをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you manipulate something, imagine you're doing it with your palm. You use your palm to manipulate the movement, and then you fine tune it further, all with your palm!

Something to note here is that you'll typically see palm in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.
Reading Mnemonic:
Where is the palm of one's hand? It's on your 手の (てのひら). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was."

Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.
Context 1-EN: I bought a small, palm-sized electronic dictionary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>掌サイズの小さな電子辞書を買いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Manipulate</kanji> your <kanji>grip</kanji> over and over. You have to manipulate it because you're slipping. You're just <vocabulary>grasping</vocabulary> right now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You probably haven’t noticed, but president Koichi holds absolute power.
Context 1-JP: <jp>恐らく気づいていないと思うが、コウイチ大統領は全てを掌握しているんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I’m just about to go hunting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これから猟に行くところだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drop of water</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>water drop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Water droplets are beading on the car windows.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車の窓には水滴がついています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>To drip</vocabulary> drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "<reading>sh*tt, ta, ta</reading> (<jp>したた</jp>), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.
Context 1-EN: The blood dripped from his forehead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の額から、血が滴り落ちました。</jp>

Meaning: Intravenous Drip,IV Drip,Raindrops,Falling Drops Of Water
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Point</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji>s are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an <vocabulary>intravenous drip</vocabulary>. Back in the day this was a way of talking about <vocabulary>raindrops</vocabulary>, or really any <vocabulary>falling drops of water</vocabulary>. But nowadays we only use it for IV drips.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After getting an IV drip, he was thoroughly examined.
Context 1-JP: <jp>点滴を受けた後、彼は綿密な診察を受けました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rut</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> left in the road are usually left by tires. This is a <vocabulary>tire track</vocabulary> left on the ground.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today I’m going down the path I took to learn English last year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、昨年の英語学習の軌跡を辿っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cook</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cook</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to boil</vocabulary>. Often it has to do with cooking grains (<vocabulary>to cook grains</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: When you cook something, it's like you're a<reading>ttack</reading>ing (<jp>たく</jp>) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!
Context 1-EN: My sister grumbled to me about how the family is in extreme poverty while she cooked rice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご飯を炊きながら、妹は私に家計が火の車だとぼやきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>cook</kanji> is <vocabulary>cooking for oneself</vocabulary>. Better break out the TV tray.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been busy, but I do cook for myself. In fact, last night I made a stewed vegetable dish called ratatouille.
Context 1-JP: <jp>忙しいけど、ちゃんと自炊してるよ。実際、昨日の夜はラタトゥイユっていう野菜の煮込み料理を作ったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>cook</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji> is the action of <vocabulary>cooking</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>culinary arts</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We hired a man to do kitchen work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕たちは、炊事をする男を雇った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>〜</jp> shows the number of tatami mats, and the <jp>畳</jp> part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a <vocabulary>counter for tatami mats</vocabulary>. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: This ten and a half mat room for just 10,000 yen a month is a first come, first served deal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>10.5畳で毎月のお家賃が一万円のこの部屋は、早い者勝ちの物件です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: An eloquent hunk passed by me and I had to do a triple-take.
Context 1-JP: <jp>爽やかなイケメンが横を通り過ぎたので、思わず三度見をしちゃいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cook</kanji> <kanji>food</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a <vocabulary>rice cooker</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We are all looking forward to Takeshi buying a rice cooker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達はみんな、剛志が炊飯器を買うのを楽しみにしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is <vocabulary>tatami mat</vocabulary>. The <jp>たたみ</jp> part, specifically.
Context 1-EN: I found his inside out, wrinkled dress shirt on the tatami where he threw it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は畳の上に脱ぎ捨てられた、表裏が逆になった皺々のワイシャツを見つけました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>bright</kanji> and <kanji>clear</kanji> has great <vocabulary>clarity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clearness</vocabulary>. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As one would expect from a veteran announcer like her, she answered the question in an easy to understand, clear voice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>さすがベテランアナウンサーなだけあって、彼女はとてもよく聞き取れる明瞭な声でその質問に答えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji>able <kanji>chopsticks</kanji> are chopsticks you can split apart. They are <vocabulary>splittable chopsticks</vocabulary>, almost always made from wood of some kind.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>割る</jp> and <jp>箸</jp> put together. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: The streets were decorated with chopsticks to welcome the Japanese prime minister.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の首相を歓迎するために、通りは割り箸で飾られました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Word of mouth spread rapidly and the foldable ceramic chopsticks became really popular.
Context 1-JP: <jp>口コミがあっという間に広がって、その折りたたみ式の陶器のお箸はとても人気が出ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: There was a beautiful rainbow above the fluttering Japanese flag.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はためく日本国旗の上には、美しい虹が掛かっていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>wick</kanji> and this word also means <vocabulary>wick</vocabulary>, but it means things at the <vocabulary>core</vocabulary> of other long things more often. Things like <vocabulary>pencil lead</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>marrow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I bought one hundred cases of HB mechanical pencil lead because they were at a bargain price.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お買い得だったので、HBのシャー芯を百ケース買いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: In a kendo match, Koichi hit the lower part of the opponent’s torso perfectly with his bamboo sword.
Context 1-JP: <jp>剣道の試合で、コウイチは竹刀で相手の胴を完璧に討ち取りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>torso</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> is the body area that's your torso. It's your <vocabulary>body</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trunk</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>torso</vocabulary>, depending on what kind of body you have.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You have the longest torso I’ve ever seen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君は今までみた中で一番胴体が長いよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>naked</kanji> <kanji>foot</kanji>, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words <jp>裸</jp> (<jp>はだか</jp>) and <jp>足</jp> (<jp>あし</jp>) were smushed together into one word. The <jp>裸</jp> becomes <jp>はだ</jp> and the <jp>足</jp> becomes <jp>し</jp>. You can think of it this way: You were <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary> too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you <reading>had ashi</reading> (<jp>はだし</jp>) at one point in the past.
Context 1-EN: You shouldn’t wear slippers barefoot if you don’t want to get athlete’s foot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水虫になりたくないなら、スリッパを裸足で履かない方がいいですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is like <jp>嬢さん</jp>, but even more polite. You usually use it when addressing a <vocabulary>young lady</vocabulary>. If your friends have any young <vocabulary>daughter</vocabulary>s, you can call them this to sound like a true lady/gentleman yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>嬢さん</jp> and uses the reading from the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Isn’t the manager’s daughter a wannabe singer?
Context 1-JP: <jp>部長のお嬢さんは確か歌手志望じゃなかったですっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>紛らわしい</jp> is "confusing" or "misleading." This is the negative of that (you can tell by the <jp>ない</jp>), meaning it's kind of the opposite of those things. This word is <vocabulary>certain</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>unmistaken</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>紛らわしい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: She is an unmistakable country bumpkin girl.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は紛れもない田舎っぺの女の子だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>狩り</jp> is hunting already. This is the same thing (<vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>狩り</jp>, so if you know that you'll know this, no need to hunt for the reading of this word.
Context 1-EN: The lookout platform we use for deer hunting is covered in a big blue tarp now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鹿狩り用の見張り台は、今は大きなブルーシートで覆われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>稼ぐ</jp> is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just <vocabulary>earnings</vocabulary>, the things you earn.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>稼ぐ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Our earnings aren’t very high, so I keep a budget account book to look at our spending habits in order to save money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>稼ぎがそんなに多くないので、何によくお金を使っているか習慣を見直して節約するために家計簿をつけています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>磨く</jp> is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your <kanji>teeth</kanji> you are brushing them. That's why this is <vocabulary>to brush one's teeth</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>歯</jp> and <jp>磨く</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: "Why don’t you brush your teeth?" "Because I like how the taste of food stays in my mouth! What’s so wrong with that?!
Context 1-JP: <jp>「どうして歯を磨かないの？」「だって、食べ物の味が口に残っているのが好きなんだもん。それっていけないことかしら？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>spear</kanji> <kanji>ahead</kanji> is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the <vocabulary>point of spear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>spearpoint</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab versions of <jp>矛</jp> and <jp>先</jp> combined together.
Context 1-EN: But, why did the hackers aim the brunt of their attack at us?
Context 1-JP: <jp>でも、どうしてハッカーは攻撃の矛先を俺たちに向けてきたんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word? Na naaa na na na na na na naaa <jp>♬</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When I went in the store the first thing I noticed was the lump of meat that was placed on the counter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>店に入ると、カウンターにドンと置かれた肉の塊がまず一番に目についた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lump</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game <vocabulary>Katamari Damacy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>塊</jp> and <jp>魂</jp> put together. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I’ve recently been playing a game called Katamari Damacy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近は塊魂というゲームをプレイしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a shop that sells books. A <vocabulary>bookstore</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones that you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I go to that bookstore often.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よくその本屋に行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This bookshop has a lot of tourist guidebooks.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この本屋には、ツアーガイドブックがたく山おいてあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I work part time at the bookstore cash register.
Context 3-JP: <jp>本屋のレジでアルバイトをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>陰</jp> is a shade or shadow. For some reason when you add <jp>お</jp> to shade it becomes "thanks to," as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." Just think about a shade helping you out. Perhaps <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary> the <kanji>shade</kanji> you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <jp>陰</jp>. <vocabulary>Thanks to</vocabulary> that other vocab word, you can read this one!
Context 1-EN: Thanks to everyone, we could go to the quarter-finals of the Japan National High School Baseball Tournament held in Koshien stadium.
Context 1-JP: <jp>皆様のお陰で、我々は甲子園球場で開催されている高校野球のトーナメントで、準々決勝にまで進出することができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Even though you have this <kanji>habit</kanji> you're still able to win. That's why this is <vocabulary>And yet</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>though</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>in spite of</vocabulary>. Because, <vocabulary>in spite of</vocabulary> your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <jp>癖</jp>.
Context 1-EN: He calls his clients suckers behind their backs and yet he bobs his head and says flattering things to their faces.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は陰では顧客のことを「カモ」と呼んでいる癖に、表ではペコペコ頭を下げておべっかを言っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>height</kanji> of your <kanji>husband</kanji> makes everything <vocabulary>safe</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary>. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "<jp>大丈夫</jp>" to mean you're doing all right.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Is this sun screen safe for babies?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この日焼け止めは、赤ちゃんに使っても大丈夫ですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Anytime is okay. I’ll go with whatever time is convenient for you, so it’s whenever you’d like.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いつでも大丈夫だよ。こっちは君の都合に合わせるから、お好きな時にどうぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Empire</kanji> (<jp>帝国</jp>) <kanji>ism</kanji> (<jp>主義</jp>) is when you are doing <vocabulary>imperialism</vocabulary>. Long live the emperor!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the two words this word is made up of, <jp>帝国</jp> and <jp>主義</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Is your country an imperialistic nation?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの国は、帝国主義国家ですか？</jp>

Meaning: Edge Of A Sumo Ring,Sumo Ring Edge,Edge,Sumo Ring
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>soil</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> on the <kanji>edge</kanji>. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the <vocabulary>edge of a sumo ring</vocabulary>. Can also be a <vocabulary>sumo ring</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The first two kanji (<jp>土俵</jp>) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji <jp>際</jp> uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.
Context 1-EN: The sumo wrestler braced himself at the edge of the ring and was able to throw his opponent out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その力士は土俵際で踏ん張り、相手力士に打っ棄りを食らわせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>椅子</jp> is a "chair." What about a <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>chair</kanji>? It's a chair with wheels. A <vocabulary>wheelchair</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>車</jp> is the vocab reading, <jp>くるま</jp>. Then, <jp>椅子</jp> is <jp>いす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Isn’t the girl in the wheelchair ridiculously sexy?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの車椅子に座ってる女の子、めちゃくちゃセクシーじゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Plow</kanji>ed <kanji>land</kanji> is called <vocabulary>arable land</vocabulary>. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The arable land is spread out in this area.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この辺りには耕地が広がっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>threat</kanji> and the noun version (here) is <vocabulary>threat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a threat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Think about a <vocabulary>threat</vocabulary> being sent to you. It's in the form of "<reading>Ode</reading> (<jp>おど</jp>) to Joy." Imagine it being sung to you. "I AM GO-ING TO GET YOU YOU CAN'T HIDE HA HA HA HA!" <jp>♬</jp>.
Context 1-EN: On the way to the sushi bar I got a threat that said I’ll be murdered if I put soy sauce on my sushi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>寿司屋に行く途中、寿司に醤油をかけたら殺すぞ、という脅しを受けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>紛れる</jp> means "to be diverted." A thing that is diverted goes in another weird direction. It's just a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: One reading does follow the <jp>紛れる</jp> reading. But the more common reading is <jp>まぐれ</jp>. Very similar to <jp>まぎれる</jp>, but the <jp>ぎ</jp> goes to <jp>ぐ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: It was just a fluke that I was able to answer the questions on the quiz.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのクイズの答えが当たったのはただの紛れです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing that will <kanji>threaten</kanji> and then <kanji>urge</kanji> you to do something else is the <vocabulary>threat</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>menace</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I called the police right after I received the threatening call, but for some reason it seemed like they didn’t want to deal with it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>脅迫電話を受けた直後に警察に電話をしましたが、彼らは何だか対応したくなさそうでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>魔法</jp> is "magic" so what about someone who <kanji>use</kanji>s <kanji>magic</kanji>? What are they called? How about a <vocabulary>wizard</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>magician</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sorcerer</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>魔法</jp> is what you learned with the kanji. The reading for <jp>使い</jp> is the same as <jp>使う</jp>.
Context 1-EN: If you don’t keep your promises people won’t take you seriously, so bring the wizard you said you met the other day!
Context 1-JP: <jp>約束を守らないと、みんなから相手にされなくなるぞ。いいから、お前が先日会ったっていう、その魔法使いを連れてこいよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cool</kanji> (temperature-wise) and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cool oneself</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cool off</vocabulary>. Whoo, that feels much cooler now.
Reading Mnemonic: You use a special product in a can <vocabulary>to cool off</vocabulary> with. Meaning: To Be Overturned,To Be Reversed,To Be Retracted,To Topple Over
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>capsize</kanji> but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going <vocabulary>to be overturned</vocabulary>. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink!
Reading Mnemonic: Of all the ideas that need to be overturned, it's the ones from the 靴 (くつがえ). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over out entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like to be retracted, 靴 guy.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t always like sports, but that was overturned once I went to see a baseball game and now I’m a big fan of the Mariners.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スポーツはずっとそんなに好きではなかったんですが、一度野球の試合を見に行った時にそれが覆りまして、今ではマリナーズの大ファンです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>diagonal</kanji> <kanji>surface</kanji> is a <vocabulary>slant</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>slope</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our driveway has become a steep slope, so you need snow tires to get up it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの私道は急斜面になってるので、上まで上がってくるにはスノータイヤがいります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Someone waves a folding fan at you, but it just blows hot air at you. "<reading>ohh gee</reading>" (<jp>おうぎ</jp>), you say. "Thanks for nothing."
Context 1-EN: Who on earth is the lady holding the violet folding fan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの、紫色の扇をもったご婦人は一体どなたですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use mnemonic to remember it instead:

You know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!
Context 1-EN: People started calling this place "Kuwabara" because there used to be a lot of mulberry fields here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かつては桑畑がたくさんあったため、この場所は「桑原」と呼ばれるようになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mulberry plantation</vocabulary>. This is more like a commercial / organized mulberry growing operation, so not some random field of mulberries.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>桑</jp> (kanji reading) and the vocab word <jp>畑</jp>. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Mulberry fields are everywhere in my hometown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の地元には、桑畑があちこちにあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>pearls</kanji>, put together on a string. This refers to a <vocabulary>rosary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prayer beads</vocabulary>. You'll see these a lot in Japan, for sale or with monks wearing them.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is different from both of the kanji readings you learned. This word sounds a lot like <reading>Jews</reading> (<jp>じゅず</jp>), so we'll have to go with that. Just imagine a Jewish rosary or prayer beads, with a Jewish person using it.
Context 1-EN: I can’t remember the name of the guy who tried to force me to buy an expensive rosary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高額な数珠を私に売りつけようとした男の名前が思い出せません。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Moist,To Be Damp,To Be Watered
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>watered</kanji>. When something is watered, it is moist and damp. That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be damp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be watered</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you get moist and damp, then <reading>you're all</reading> (<jp>うるお</jp>) wet. It's just how it is.

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>inferiority</kanji> has <kanji>change</kanji>d. In fact, it's getting worse and worse, changing by the minute. Each minute that goes by is another minute where you're getting worse. This is <vocabulary>deterioration</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>輝く</jp> is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be <vocabulary>radiance</vocabulary>. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.

Context 1-EN: I was disoriented by the radiance of the diamond.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はそのダイヤモンドの輝きに目がくらんでしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who is <kanji>bad</kanji> but also <kanji>clever</kanji> (<jp>賢い</jp>) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as <vocabulary>devious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>cunning</vocabulary>, or other things.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>悪い</jp> and <jp>賢い</jp> combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: He’s such a cunning guy and he’s very good at feigning innocence too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは悪賢い男で、猫かぶりが大のお得意なんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The great <kanji>alligator</kanji>! This can mean both <vocabulary>alligator</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crocodile</vocabulary>, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.
Context 1-EN: This alligator statue is in the way.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この鰐の置物、邪魔なんだけど。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You can handwrite the kanji for WaniKani without looking at anything? That's amazing!
Context 2-JP: <jp>鰐蟹って漢字、何も見ずに手書きで書けるの？すごいね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a stuffed alligator displayed in my room.
Context 3-JP: <jp>鰐の剥製が部屋に飾ってあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ridge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Look up at the <vocabulary>summit</vocabulary>. It's such a <reading>mean</reading> (<jp>みね</jp>) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

Context 1-JP: <jp>妹と私は、雲の上にそびえる富士山の峰に登頂しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually these types of <vocabulary>mound</vocabulary>s are <vocabulary>burial mound</vocabulary>s. (There's bodies under there!)
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>明瞭</jp> is "<kanji>clarity</kanji>." If there is <kanji>not</kanji> any of this clarity, then you have <vocabulary>dimness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>obscurity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Take along</kanji> this <kanji>summit</kanji> and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a <vocabulary>mountain range</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の連峰はよく晴れていて見晴らしがいいです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're so <kanji>adept</kanji>! That makes you <vocabulary>adept</vocabulary> at that thing. <vocabulary>Skillful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> are other ways to do it too.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means <vocabulary>cannabis</vocabulary> as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>profit</kanji>s that I'm <kanji>watered</kanji> with are pouring all over me. That's my <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>returns</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Vulgar</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> isn't necessarily bad words, or something like that. It's just rougher and not as standard as standard language. It is a <vocabulary>colloquialism</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>colloquial language</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wind</kanji> that is <kanji>wicked</kanji> comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of <jp>風</jp> (<jp>かぜ</jp>). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wicked</kanji> <kanji>devil</kanji>! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a <vocabulary>hindrance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intrusion</vocabulary>. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Pleasant</kanji> <kanji>comfort</kanji> brings you a lot of <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary> and you get a lot of <vocabulary>enjoyment</vocabulary> out of it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being <vocabulary>wicked</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Evil</vocabulary>, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the <reading><jp>横島</jp></reading> (<jp>よこしま</jp>).

Context 1-JP: <jp>神様は私の邪な心を見透かしていらっしゃったんだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a <vocabulary>shogi piece</vocabulary> too, since that's Japanese chess, after all.

Meaning Mnemonic: Look <kanji>below</kanji> you. These things carry your <kanji>burdensome</kanji> weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically <vocabulary>geta</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Japanese wooden clogs</vocabulary>. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>駄</jp> is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of <jp>だ</jp> it's <jp>た</jp>. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらの下駄は二色のお色をご用意しております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>notebook</kanji> that is also a <kanji>record book</kanji> is an <vocabulary>account book</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>register</vocabulary>, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>stab</kanji> from <kanji>China</kanji> is <vocabulary>sudden</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unexpected</vocabulary>. Whoa, what? China, why would you stab me? I thought we were neighbors? No, I thought we were friends?!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You want clear, concise <vocabulary>public recognition</vocabulary> for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>manga</kanji> <kanji>drawing</kanji> is <vocabulary>manga</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>Japanese comics</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Lotus</kanji> <kanji>root</kanji> is <vocabulary>lotus root</vocabulary>.

Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is like the reading of <jp>包み</jp>, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary> that's made purely from bundles and packages. These <reading><jp>包み</jp></reading> (<jp>つつみ</jp>) are the only thing holding the water in!
Context 1-EN: The village head decided to bury a human sacrifice in the embankment to prevent it from collapsing.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>embankment</kanji> <kanji>prevent</kanji>s the water from going over the edge. It's an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You're going <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary> away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "<reading>ta da yo</reading>-yo (<jp>ただよ</jp>)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.
Context 1-EN: Farts after eating roasted sweet potatoes seem to hang in the air longer than normal farts.

Meaning Mnemonic: Something has <kanji>drift</kanji>ed to the point where it has <kanji>arrive</kanji>d. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word <vocabulary>drifting ashore</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Drifting</kanji> down the <kanji>stream</kanji>. Something that is doing this is <vocabulary>drifting</vocabulary>. It could also be the <vocabulary>drift</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>帆が折れて、ヨットが海に漂流し始めた時は、ちょっと悲観的でしたね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>flip</kanji> your <kanji>idea</kanji> of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is <vocabulary>change one's mind</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>この結婚について、絶対に翻意することがないことを誓います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Flip</kanji> the <kanji>translation</kanji> of a word from one language to another. That is the <vocabulary>translation</vocabulary> of that word (or phrase, etc).

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means <kanji>flip</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean <vocabulary>to suddenly change</vocabulary> your mind, or your attitude, etc.
Reading Mnemonic: For something <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, you'll need to ask the <reading>here guy</reading> (<jp>ひるがえ</jp>) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.
Context 1-EN: I know her skirt billowed in the wind, but rendering how I felt at the time is too difficult.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女のスカートが風で翻ったのは分かるんですが、その時の彼の心象を翻訳するのは私には難しすぎます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rut</kanji> in the <kanji>road</kanji> is for some reason an <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary>. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary> that will send you into <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary>. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Everyone was delighted to hear the news that the rocket entered orbit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ロケットが軌道に入ったというニュースを聞いて、誰もが喜びました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>interest</kanji> is <kanji>stirred up</kanji>! I'm feeling <vocabulary>excitement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stimulation</vocabulary> from all this stirring up, in fact!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>興奮</jp> is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of <jp>きょう</jp> it's <jp>こう</jp>, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to <reading><jp>こう</jp></reading>. So just think of <jp>こういち</jp> exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.
Context 1-EN: Every time I ignore a stop sign I get excited.
Context 1-JP: <jp>止まれの標識を無視する度に、興奮するんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm <kanji>stirred up</kanji> causing me to <kanji>wake up</kanji>. I'm <vocabulary>stirring</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rousing oneself</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>believe</kanji> and <kanji>look up to</kanji> a higher power, for I have <vocabulary>religious faith</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>仰</jp> portion is an exceptional one. Instead of <jp>ぎょう</jp> it's <jp>こう</jp>. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is <reading><jp>こう</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I believe in Christianity and I have unwavering faith in God.

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>look up to</kanji> <kanji>heaven</kanji>, and I am <vocabulary>taken aback</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amazed</vocabulary> by it. It's just so amazing.

Context 1-EN: I was astonished at how quickly Mami could eat bacon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は真美がどれだけ速くベーコンを食べれるのかってことにびっくり仰天しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>mother</kanji> isn't your own mother, but she is the chief of your mother. She's your mother's lady sibling, who has always owned your mom. She's the chief mother. She's your <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>母</jp> part is just the first <jp>は</jp> in <jp>はは</jp>, rendaku'd. You can also think of your <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary> as a sheep, too, if you'd like.
Context 1-EN: I wonder why my aunt didn’t come to our wedding ceremony.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伯母はどうして私達の結婚式に来ようとしなかったんだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>chief</kanji> of this district is that guy, the <vocabulary>count</vocabulary>. He's also the <vocabulary>earl</vocabulary> of another district, and the <vocabulary>chief</vocabulary> of yet another.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>はく</jp> reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: How about giving Fugu the title of an earl, and calling him Count Fugu?
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグの爵位を伯爵にして、フグ伯って呼ぶことにするのはどうかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something you do <kanji>accidentally</kanji> is hopefully something you do <vocabulary>occasionally</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>once in a while</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: For the reading, think about the word <jp>弾</jp> (<jp>たま</jp>), which means bullet, and how you <vocabulary>occasionally</vocabulary> shoot people with bullets when you're out hunting... but not too often. Dick Cheney level.
Context 1-EN: I strain my back every once in a while.
Context 1-JP: <jp>偶にぎっくり腰になるんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Accidentally</kanji> but <kanji>naturally</kanji> (as in nothing was set up artificially before). So, the accident was a true, natural accident. This kind of accident is something that happens <vocabulary>by chance</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>unexpectedly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I unexpectedly ran into a friend from high school at the airport.
Context 1-JP: <jp>空港で偶然、高校時代の友人に会ったんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>eddy</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about <vocabulary>Yodogawa</vocabulary>. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>淀</jp> plus <jp>川</jp>. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: The dirty water didn’t stop her swimming in the Yodogawa.
Context 1-JP: <jp>汚い水にも怯まず、彼女は淀川で泳いだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Distribute</kanji> yourself <kanji>accidentally</kanji> to <kanji>someone</kanji>. That person ended up becoming your <vocabulary>spouse</vocabulary>. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been thinking about looking for a new spouse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい配偶者を探そうかとずっと考えているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>tomb</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ancient tomb</vocabulary> though it can refer to the <vocabulary>ancient mound</vocabulary>s (of the Jomon, I'm assuming).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>近年その古墳を訪れる人が増えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's so <kanji>robust</kanji> and <kanji>big</kanji>! Things like this are <vocabulary>magnificent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>grand</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>epic</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tomb</kanji> <kanji>grave</kanji> is a <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>... or it could be a <vocabulary>tomb</vocabulary>. Or maybe both.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>ツタンカーメンの墳墓は絶対に訪れた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Feeling so <kanji>robust</kanji> I just want to get up and <kanji>go</kanji>! It's so <vocabulary>rousing</vocabulary>!

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>robust</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are the best years of your life! This is the <vocabulary>prime of life</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>彼のお兄さんは壮年期に心臓発作を起こして亡くなりました。</jp>

Meaning: Counter For Bundles,Counter for Bunches,Bundle Counter,Bunch Counter
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji refers to a <kanji>bundle</kanji>, but this refers to a <vocabulary>counter for bundles</vocabulary>. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
Reading Mnemonic: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: <jp>わ</jp> for <reading>wa</reading>lrus (<jp>わ</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: Wow! A bunch of spinach is only ninety-eight yen!
Context 1-JP: <jp>わっ！ほうれん草一把で九十八円だって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Using the <kanji>grasp</kanji> meaning of <jp>把</jp> and combining it with <kanji>grip</kanji>, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean <vocabulary>grasp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>catch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Honestly, I haven’t even been able to grasp the overall situation yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>正直、まだ事態の把握すら出来ていない状況です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>carry</kanji> you and <kanji>transport</kanji> you. That's a form of <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary>. Could also be a <vocabulary>carriage</vocabulary>, which is also a form of transport.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

Context 1-JP: <jp>このレストランには、食事やその他の細々したものを運搬するためのミニエレベータがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that <kanji>transport</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> you places are forms of <vocabulary>transportation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>搬送作業時に左肩を脱臼してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>liquid crystal</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Transport</kanji> and <kanji>exit</kanji> these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to <vocabulary>carry out</vocabulary>.

Context 1-JP: <jp>日曜の夜七時までに全ての作品を搬出する必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>crystal</vocabulary>. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>cave</kanji> is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a <vocabulary>hollow</vocabulary>, but can also refer to a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A polar bear was snoozing in the hollow of a tree and a lumberjack soon came along.
Context 1-JP: <jp>白熊が木の空洞の中でうたた寝をしていると、近くに木こりがやって来ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>Hoe Ra</reading> (<jp>ほら</jp>), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.
Context 1-EN: The eerie cave stood silently in the outskirts north of the village.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その薄気味悪い洞は、村の北外れにひっそりと佇んでいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>criminal</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> will end up as a <vocabulary>prisoner</vocabulary> if they get caught!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do prisoners wear striped clothes?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして囚人は縞々の服を着ているんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have senior high school! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate).

Fun fact: 高校 is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Right after graduating from his senior high school, Koichi joined the navy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは高等学校を卒業してすぐ海軍に入りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There was a senior high school that was famous for celebrities going there, near the condo I used to live in when I was little.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私がまだ小さかった時に住んでいたマンションの近くに芸能人が通うことで有名な高等学校がありました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m the vice principal of a senior high school.
Context 3-JP: <jp>高等学校で教頭をしております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cave</kanji> <kanji>hole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>den</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading of <jp>洞</jp> is one you've learned. The reading of <jp>穴</jp> isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary>, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<jp>けつ</jp>). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say <jp>ほらあな</jp>, but then you'd never learn that reading for <jp>穴</jp>, and where's the fun in that?
Context 1-EN: I stumbled into the cave and sprained my ankle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その洞穴で躓いて、足首を捻挫しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We have to <kanji>examine</kanji> you during this <kanji>epidemic</kanji>... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a <vocabulary>quarantine</vocabulary>, sorry about that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Australia’s quarantine laws are very strict, so you shouldn’t take any food there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>オーストラリアの検疫法はすっごく厳しいから、食べ物は何も持って行かない方が身のためだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>life</kanji> <kanji>horizon</kanji> is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is <vocabulary>one's lifetime</vocabulary>, though it could also refer to <vocabulary>one's career</vocabulary>. Basically, at the end of it something dies.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t want to stay single my whole life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生涯ずっと独身なんて嫌だよう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>excuse</kanji> yourself from the <kanji>epidemic</kanji>, you'll have to have <vocabulary>immunity</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immunization</vocabulary> from the disease.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I went to the doctor because I always have a slight fever and terrible headache, and I was told that my immune system is weakening.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつも微熱とひどい頭痛があるのでお医者さんに行ったら、免疫機能が弱ってきていると言われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>恨む</jp> is "to hold a grudge." This is the noun version, which is a <vocabulary>grudge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>恨む</jp>, so if you know that no need to hold a grudge.
Context 1-EN: I asked for an appointment, but he wouldn’t give me the time of day because he apparently has a some kind of grudge against the president of our company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アポを取ろうとしたんだけど、彼はどうやらうちの社長に何か恨みがあるみたいで、時間をくれなかったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>epidemic</kanji> of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is going to come from an <vocabulary>infectious disease</vocabulary>. Perhaps a <vocabulary>plague</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>epidemic</vocabulary> of some kind?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Everyone in that village died from the plague.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その村の人々は、全員疫病で亡くなりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>憩う</jp> is to rest, then this noun version (I know it looks like an adjective, but it's not) would be <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>憩う</jp>, so if you know that you can rest easy.
Context 1-EN: I want to make my restaurant a place of rest and relaxation for busy salarymen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はうちの食堂を忙しいサラリーマンの憩いの場にしたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something is <kanji>pathetic</kanji> then you should try <vocabulary>to pity</vocabulary> that thing.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>Awww</reading> (<jp>あわ</jp>), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from <jp>哀れ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I heard her grandmother grumble, "That girl’s shyness should be pitied."
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女のお婆さんが、「あの子の人見知りは哀れむべきものだ」とぼやくのを聞きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>threaten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: I'm going <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary> you with your life if you have a bad <reading>odo</reading>r (<jp>おど</jp>). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.
Context 1-EN: That teacher was fired because he threatened some male students with a knife.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その教師は何名かの男子生徒を刃物で脅したとして解雇されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>飢える</jp> is "to starve." The noun version is <vocabulary>hunger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>starvation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>飢える</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My heart aches whenever I see the pictures of those starving children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飢えに苦しむ子どもたちの写真を見る度に胸が痛みます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>gentle</kanji> and <kanji>soft</kanji> thing will be really <vocabulary>flexible</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pliable</vocabulary>. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>このホテルは色々な要望に柔軟に対応してくれます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: <vocabulary>coloring</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色g, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t like my dad’s bento because he never really took coloring into account and all of it was brown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父の弁当は、彩りについて全く考慮がされておらず、全部茶色だったので嫌でしたね。</jp>

Meaning: To Exhaust,To Run Out,To Do To Exhaustion
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>尽きる</jp> is "to exhaust." <jp>尽くす</jp> is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it <vocabulary>to exhaust</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>尽きる</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Can you do this by tomorrow?" "I see, I’ll give it my best."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「これ、明日までにできるかな？」「わかりました。最善を尽くします。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>regret</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to regret</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mourn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>悔しい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Whenever I wake up with a pounding headache, I lament drinking too much the night before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ガンガン響く頭と共に目を覚ます度に、前日の夜飲み過ぎたことを悔やみます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>詐欺</jp> is "fraud." An <kanji>expert</kanji> at <kanji>fraud</kanji> (<jp>詐欺</jp>) is someone who does this a lot and possibly for a living. A <vocabulary>swindler</vocabulary>, some would say.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of <jp>詐欺</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: "Hey, did you just call me a liar?" "No, but I called you a crook." "Huh? What are you talking about!? I seriously can’t believe you."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、今俺のこと、嘘つきって言った？」「そうは言ってないけど、詐欺師とは言ったよ。」「はぁ？何言ってんだよ。マジ、信じらんねぇ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>assault</kanji> then <kanji>crowd</kanji>. That means you're assaulting a place, then crowding into it, presumably doing a <vocabulary>raid</vocabulary> on the place.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>殴る</jp> and <jp>込む</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We had an early lunch before the raid.
Context 1-JP: <jp>殴り込みの前に早めの昼食を取りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>殴る</jp>, which means "to punch"? Well, add on <jp>合う</jp> and you've got <vocabulary>punches</vocabulary> that have <vocabulary>come together</vocabulary> with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a <vocabulary>fistfight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>殴る</jp> and <jp>合う</jp>, punched together.
Context 1-EN: My man is in the middle of the fist fight in the club.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の連れは今クラブで殴り合いの喧嘩の真っ最中さ。</jp>

Meaning: Red Light District,Pleasure Quarters,World Of The Geisha
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>red light district</kanji> (<jp>花柳</jp>) <kanji>world</kanji> of the red light district is the <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>, though this can refer especially to the "<vocabulary>pleasure quarters</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>world of the geisha</vocabulary>" as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve always dreamed of experiencing the red-light district.
Context 1-JP: <jp>花柳界を経験してみるのが夢だったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accomplish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to accomplish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky <reading>toe</reading> (<jp>と</jp>)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.
Context 1-EN: Don’t give up! Accomplish it! You can do it!
Context 1-JP: <jp>諦めないで！やり遂げるんだ！お前なら出来るよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hemp</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hemp cloth</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of <jp>麻</jp> and <jp>布</jp> combined together.
Context 1-EN: I like clothes made of hemp cloth, but they’re rather expensive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>麻布の服が好きなんだけど、結構お値段が高いんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>sticky</kanji> things are really <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary> and covered with <vocabulary>stickiness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>粘る</jp>. I suppose you <reading>never never</reading> want to touch something <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I removed my dog’s ear wax with a cotton swab and it was kind of sticky. Is it normal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>綿棒で犬の耳垢を取ったら何だか粘々していたんですが、それは普通ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rest</kanji> (<jp>休憩</jp>) <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rest area</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rest stop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: The man they arrested is suspected of breaking into the rest area.
Context 1-JP: <jp>逮捕された男は、休憩所に不法侵入した疑いがかけられていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If 歩 is "walk" and you take one walk, then really you are just taking one step. When there's a number before 歩, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The <jp>いち</jp> shortens to an <jp>いっ</jp> and the <jp>ほ</jp> rendakus to <jp>ぽ</jp>. One step at a time, right?
Context 1-EN: I’ve finally taken one step forward toward my dream.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ようやく、ゆめに向かって一歩ふみ出しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They say, a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
Context 2-JP: <jp>千里の道も一歩からって言うでしょ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: It takes courage to take the first step forward.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最初の一歩を踏み出すのに勇気がいる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji refers to a <kanji>floor</kanji> (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a <jp>〜</jp>. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the <jp>〜</jp> or you'll get it wrong!
Context 1-EN: "Which floor?" "Fourth please." "This elevator doesn't stop on that floor."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「何階ですか？」「四階をおねがいします。」「このエレベーターはその階には止まりませんよ。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi lives on the top floor of a ninety-nine story apartment building.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、九十九階だてのマンションの最上階に住んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I live on the thirteenth floor of this apartment.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このアパートの十三階に住んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji <jp>付</jp> means <kanji>attach</kanji> and words like <jp>付く</jp> mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps <vocabulary>included</vocabulary> with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast<jp>付き</jp>, i.e. "<vocabulary>including</vocabulary> breakfast."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like <jp>付く</jp> and <jp>付ける</jp>.
Context 1-EN: This vacuum cleaner comes with one year warranty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このそうじきは、一年間のほしょうしょ付きですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm looking for a Japanese style hotel that includes dinner and breakfast.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一ぱく二食付きのりょかんをさがしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This room is furnished with a refrigerator and a washing machine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この部屋は冷蔵庫、洗濯機付きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you can <kanji>dedicate</kanji> yourself to <kanji>go</kanji>ing to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good <vocabulary>magistrate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you:

The magistrate is the only person who's allowed to drink booze and eat gyoza (ぶぎょう). If you see someone simultaneously drinking booze and eating dumplings in Japan, you'll know that person is the magistrate!
Context 1-EN: Tadasuke Ooka was promoted to magistrate at a young age.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大岡忠相は、若くして江戸町奉行に昇進した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you take this compass to the shogunate administrator's office over there?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この羅針盤をあそこの奉行所に届けてくれないか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: When we have nabe, my boyfriend always takes charge of the nabe, so it's easy for me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>鍋の時はいつも彼氏が鍋奉行してくれるんで、楽なんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>ravine</kanji> in the water connecting two <kanji>sea</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>channel</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>strait</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’ll cross the channel in this ferry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このフェリーで海峡を渡ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a counter that can be used with various "flat" things, which is why it is referring to a <vocabulary>flat object</vocabulary>. Other things it can refer to include <vocabulary>clothing items</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sheets</vocabulary>, paper, stamps, dishes, and more. Notice how they're all kind of flat shaped?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have ten tickets for the soccer game on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日曜日のサッカーの試合のチケットを十枚持っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My breakfast is usually just one slice of toast.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつもは朝ご飯は食パン一枚だけです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’d like to buy some Tofugu stickers. How much would one be?
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguのステッカーを何枚か買いたいのですが、一枚いくらになりますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>auspicious</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> from another world is your <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> story. You originally came from another place, and you had to leave there gloriously before you could enter this world.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Dekopon is a kind of mandarin orange that originated in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>デコポンは日本発祥のみかんの品種です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s. What does that come out to? <vocabulary>Three hundred</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the <jp>ひゃく</jp> rendakus to <jp>びゃく</jp>. This pattern will repeat itself with <jp>三</jp> + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.
Context 1-EN: I have three hundred manga.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まんがを三百さつもっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was taking a nap, somebody rang the doorbell 300 times.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ひるねをしていた時に、だれかがインターホンを三百回もならした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: One year is three hundred and sixty-five days.

Meaning: Big Machine,Big Device,Machine,Device,Machine Counter,Number Of Machines
Meaning Mnemonic: This counter is used with some kind of <kanji>machine</kanji> or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the <jp>〜</jp> in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.
Context 1-EN: How many buses do we need?
Context 1-JP: <jp>バスはなん台いりますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ordered three machines that makes your eyesight better.
Context 2-JP: <jp>し力がよくなるきかいを三台ちゅうもんしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The rich company president has three luxury cars.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あのかねもちしゃちょうはこうきゅうしゃを三台もっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>beat</kanji>ing in your <kanji>vein</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>pulse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The pulse has already stopped.
Context 1-JP: <jp>すでに脈拍が止まっている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>city</kanji> is a <vocabulary>city</vocabulary>. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This bronze statue of Koichi has become the symbol of this city.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このコウイチのどうぞうは、この都市のシンボルになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I prefer life in the city as opposed to life in the countryside.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いなかよりも、都市での生活の方がいいですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you know any interesting urban legends?
Context 3-JP: <jp>何かおもしろい都市伝説を知っていますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>地下</jp>, which is "below ground." Well, this is <kanji>ground</kanji> and <kanji>above</kanji> combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means <vocabulary>above ground</vocabulary>. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really <vocabulary>on the ground</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The leaves fell to the ground.
Context 1-JP: <jp> 木のはが地上におちた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi has a Secret Base 1km above ground.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは地上1kmの所に、ひみつき地をもっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you look at Tokyo Tower from the ground it feels tremendously powerful.
Context 3-JP: <jp>東京タワーは、地上から見上げると物凄い迫力がありますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>say</kanji> words in a <kanji>language</kanji>, you are speaking a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary>. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What are the popular programming languages right now?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今人気のプログラミング言語は何ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I joined an offline gathering where language geeks got together and talk about language all night long.
Context 2-JP: <jp>言語オタクたちが朝まで言語について語りつくすオフ会にさんかしてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I started to study a new computer language.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しいコンピュータ言語の勉強を始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If there's a number before <jp>時</jp>, it means <vocabulary>o'clock</vocabulary>. For example <jp>１時</jp> is 1:00, and <jp>２３時</jp> is 23:00 or 11pm.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: When it’s three o’clock let’s have our afternoon snack break.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三時になったらおやつ休けいにしましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's meet up at Koichi's kitchen at 2:30, ok?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの家の台どころで二時半にまちあわせね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you usually do your WaniKani reviews at 3pm?
Context 3-JP: <jp>いつも１５時にワニカニのレビューをするんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you take <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s and put them together, you have <vocabulary>all</vocabulary> things. The <vocabulary>entire</vocabulary> collection. It is <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: All of it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>全部ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who ate the whole box of my bacon cookies?
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのベーコンクッキーを一はこ全部食べちゃったのはだれ！？</jp>
Context 3-EN: All of these socks have holes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この靴下、全部穴があいていますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If we're talking about <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>s, then we might as well be talking about <vocabulary>all people</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>, because that's a lot of people, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>万</jp> is a bit weird. It's <jp>ばん</jp> instead of <jp>まん</jp>. So, when you think of this word and think of <vocabulary>all people</vocabulary>, think about how they're all cheering "<reading>ban</reading>zai!" at the same time, together. BANZAI BANZAI ALL PEOPLE RULE.
Context 1-EN: That actor is popular with everyone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このはいゆうは、万人に人気がある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that everybody likes the smell of parakeets.
Context 2-JP: <jp>セキセイインコのにおいは万人にうけるにおいらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This seems to be the common impression among everybody.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これは万人に共通の感想だろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>flavor</kanji> of this <kanji>direction</kanji> is one I'd like to follow and go in, along with you. You have a good flavor and you're going in a good direction. Will you be my <vocabulary>ally</vocabulary>? I'll be your <vocabulary>supporter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <jp>味</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>方</jp>. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to read this word!
Context 1-EN: I thought that at least Tofugu would support me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグだけは、味方してくれると思ってたんだけどな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Actually, Koichi was an enemy disguised as a friend.
Context 2-JP: <jp>実は、コウイチは味方のふりをしたてきだったんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Who the heck are your allies?
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前は一体どっちの味方なんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just remember that this word can be used for both animal and seed shells.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Shells come from (から) living animals. You can't have a shell — or a carapace (から) — unless something was once in there. They have to come from something.

This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too. 🌱
Context 1-EN: Please put crab shells on this plate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>蟹の殻はこの皿に入れてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What do we do after removing the husks from wheat?
Context 2-JP: <jp>麦の殻を取ったら、その次はどうするの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I watched a video that captured the moment when a seed breaks through its shell and sprouts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>種の殻を突き破って、芽が出てくる瞬間を捉えたビデオを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you see this on a number, for example <jp>７人</jp> or <jp>３人</jp>, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both <jp>一人</jp> and <jp>二人</jp> have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus <jp>にん</jp>, like this. <jp>５人</jp> is <jp>ごにん</jp>, <jp>１０人</jp> is <jp>じゅうにん</jp>, etc. This is the counter for people, which makes this word the <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>にん</jp> reading of this kanji. Just think of a <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary>, all <reading>nin</reading>jas, standing there as you count them out.
Context 1-EN: There were 10 people, altogether.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぜんぶで十人いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many workers are in Tofugu?
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグにはなん人のしゃいんがいますか？</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>わたしは三人子どもがいます。</jp>

Meaning: Now For Sale,In Stores Now,Now Available
Meaning Mnemonic: You have <jp>発売</jp>, which means "for sale," and then you have <jp>中</jp> which is <kanji>middle</kanji>. An item that is in the middle of being for sale is <vocabulary>now for sale</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>in stores now</vocabulary> or in other words <vocabulary>now available</vocabulary>. You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>発売</jp> and <jp>中</jp> (kanji reading) put together.
Context 1-EN: Is the Year-End Jumbo Draw Lottery still for sale?
Context 1-JP: <jp>年末ジャンボたからくじはまだ発売中ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a tenugui towel that's sold on the Tofugu store.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは、トーフグストアで発売中の手ぬぐいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The June issue of Shonen Jump is now on sale, to critical acclaim.
Context 3-JP: <jp>少年ジャンプ６月号、ただ今絶賛発売中。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>手洗い</jp> is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add <jp>お</jp> you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>. Ewww. Poop goes there.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>手洗い</jp>, so if you know that you'll know this too!
Context 1-EN: The restroom is straight and to the left.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お手洗いは、真っすぐ行って左です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>自動</jp> is <kanji>automatic</kanji>. So what is an automatic <kanji>car</kanji>? That is an <vocabulary>automobile</vocabulary>, or simply a <vocabulary>car</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>自動</jp> and the kanji <jp>車</jp>'s readings, combined.
Context 1-EN: I feel betrayed by that car dealership.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの自動車ディーラーにうら切られた気分です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are trying to set some money aside for a new car.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新しい自動車を買うために、お金をためるようにしています。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>自動車の運転免許を失くしてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>attack</kanji>! This is a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> on someone or something, though it can also be an <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> on them. Yep, this is the <jp>進撃</jp> from <jp>進撃の巨人</jp> the popular anime / manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!
Context 1-EN: I’m hooked on Attack on Titan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>進撃の巨人にはまっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji> is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're <vocabulary>glasses</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses!

This word can also be read as がんきょう, but usually only on official/written documents. If you're speaking and not reading a government document, you should say めがね!
Context 1-EN: You should wipe your glasses.
Context 1-JP: <jp>眼鏡を拭いた方がいいですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>board</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blackboard</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the <jp>はん</jp> changing to <jp>ばん</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We can’t use the blackboard so I’ll bring in a whiteboard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>黒板が使えないので、ホワイトボードを持参しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Just like the meaning of the kanji (<kanji>fast</kanji>) this adjective also means <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>早い</jp> means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary> to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).
Context 1-EN: The shinkansen is faster than a normal train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新かん線はふつうの電車より速いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We had a competition to see who could swim from Portland to Tokyo the fastest.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポートランドから東京まで、だれが一番速く泳げるかきょうそうしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In my family, we eat dinner really fast.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちの家族は、ご飯を食べるのがとても速いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>north</kanji> <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is the road you take to get to the northern sea. That is an area of Japan, actually. That area is known as <vocabulary>Hokkaido</vocabulary>. It's a very nice place, be sure to visit it if you can for some of the freshest seafood around.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>ほく</jp> does get shortened though, so be careful!
Context 1-EN: I’ve gone yukigassen snowball fighting in Hokkaido.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぼくは、北海道で雪合せんをしたことがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've arrived in Hokkaido! Time to eat some real sushi!
Context 2-JP: <jp>北海道についたどー！本もののすしを食べるどー！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Speaking of Hokkaido souvenirs, what’s famous?
