Context 3-JP: <jp>北海道のお土産といえば、何が有名でしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is a <vocabulary>new year</vocabulary>. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Happy New Year!
Context 1-JP: <jp>新年、明けましておめでとうございます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you decided your New Year's resolution yet?
Context 2-JP: <jp>新年のほうふはもう決めましたか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: We went around to our relatives houses exchanging New Year’s greetings.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新年の挨拶に、親戚の家を回りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing you use to <kanji>teach</kanji> a <kanji>course</kanji> with <kanji>writing</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>textbook</vocabulary>. It's a book of writings you use to teach your course!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can't buy the Japanese textbook because it's too expensive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その日本語の教科書は高すぎて買えません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please don't share the textbook. Each person must buy their own.
Context 2-JP: <jp>教科書はシェアしないで一人一さつ買ってくださいね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I forgot to bring my textbook and I was kept an hour after school.
Context 3-JP: <jp>教科書を持ってくるのを忘れたせいで、放課後一時間学校に残されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>循環</jp> means "circulation" or "cycle," so adding <kanji>bad</kanji> to that makes it a <vocabulary>vicious cycle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: First of all, it’s important to cut off the vicious cycle in your heart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まずは、あなたの心の悪循環を断ち切ることが大切です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>足りる</jp>? That is "to be enough." How can you make something be enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where there are enough! That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary>, because you keep adding until you <jp>足りる</jp>. Maybe you add so much that someone tries to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you for that nasty pile of squirrels you keep outside.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>足りる</jp>, so if you know that you can add things up to this.
Context 1-EN: Three plus two is five.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三足す二は五です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Maybe it would be better to add more water to this soup.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このスープ、もう少し水を足した方がいいんじゃないかな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can you add a little more to this sentence here?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここにもう少し文章を書き足すことはできますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>need</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to need</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going <vocabulary>to need</vocabulary>... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an <reading>ea</reading>gle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.
Context 1-EN: You need onions, tomatoes, and daikon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>玉ねぎとトマトと大こんが要ります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Write out a list of things you do and don’t need.
Context 3-JP: <jp>要るものと要らないものをリストに書き出しなさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>cleanse</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> it becomes <vocabulary>clean water</vocabulary> that you can drink.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I almost had a three hundred thousand yen water filter sold to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三十万円の浄水器を売りつけられそうになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going <vocabulary>to sit</vocabulary> down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking <reading>sewer</reading> (<jp>すわ</jp>). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.
Context 1-EN: Could you not sit on the important documents?
Context 1-JP: <jp>大事な書類の上に座らないでもらえますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi and Viet are always playing whoopee cushion pranks, so I'm always careful when I sit down on my office chair.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチとビエトはいつもブーブークッションでいたずらするのでオフィスのいすに座る時は気をつけている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I’m sitting for a long time my butt gets sweaty.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ずっと座っていると、お尻が汗ばんできます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>car</kanji> with more cars on <kanji>both</kanji> sides is a car that hooks into other cars... specifically other <vocabulary>railroad car</vocabulary>s. They have hooks on both sides, they hook into other cars, and they fit all the requirements of this vocab word's kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Hi there, I’m examining the railroad cars.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ただいま、車両の点けんをしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Japan, vehicles drive on the left side of the road.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本では、車両は左がわを走ります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This railroad car is a women-only carriage.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この車両は女性専用車両です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>wound</kanji> is a <vocabulary>burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scald</vocabulary> you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a <vocabulary>burn</vocabulary> (on your arm) being caused by a <reading>yakky do</reading>do (<jp>やけど</jp>) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.
Context 1-EN: I spilled curry and got a burn on my hand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カレーを零して、手に火傷を負った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>truth</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> is when you feel something is true. You have the <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary> this is a <vocabulary>real feeling</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading for <jp>実</jp> gets changed to <jp>じっ</jp> so be careful!
Context 1-EN: When I look at this revenue chart I really feel like WaniKani is selling well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この売り上げ表を見ると、ワニカニが売れているんだなと実感できます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even when I heard the news that my mother died, it didn't feel real at first.
Context 2-JP: <jp>母が死んだという知らせを聞いても、すぐには実感がわかなかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Only after I went to America did I realize how small Japan really is.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカへ行って初めて、日本はなんと小さい国かと実感した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>discuss</kanji> is when you sit and look at another person. You are discussing something versus them, so you talk back and forth to each other. In this way, you are having a <vocabulary>conversation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The dream of Koichi and Steve Buscemi talking came true!
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチとスティーヴ・ブシェミのゆめの対談が実げんしました！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Unfortunately, it's time to bring this conversation to a close.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ざんねんながら、そろそろこの対談をおわらせる時間になってしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to talk with a famous writer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>有名な作家と対談してみたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>read</kanji>ing <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is reading. They are the <vocabulary>reader</vocabulary> (of a book, blog, article, etc).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>読</jp> is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is <jp>どく</jp>, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the <vocabulary>reader</vocabulary>, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful <reading>dock</reading> (<jp>どく</jp>). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu readers paid for my plane tickets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの読者が、飛行機代を出してくれたんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu has many readers all over the world.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグには世界中にたくさんの読者がいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Among Tofugu readers, how many are Japanese language learners?
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの読者のうち、日本語学習者はどのくらいいますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have an <kanji>idea</kanji> of what you <kanji>want</kanji> already, then that's good! You have <vocabulary>will</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary>. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I showed the will to win a gold medal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>金メダル獲得に意欲をみせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> (aka "a thing you eat") is <vocabulary>food</vocabulary>. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: Please bring some food, Ms. Yasuda.
Context 1-JP: <jp>安田さんは、食べ物をおねがいします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've always had issues with eating whenever I get sad or depressed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かなしい時や、おちこんでいる時は、いつも食べ物がのどを通らなくなってしまうんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you waste food, heaven will punish you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>食べ物を粗末にするとバチが当たりますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>squeeze</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to squeeze</vocabulary>. The way that this word differs from <jp>絞る</jp> is that the former means "to wring out" and the latter means to squeeze or <vocabulary>to juice</vocabulary> fruits/vegetables or <vocabulary>to milk</vocabulary> a cow.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

After the farmer milks the cow, she bows (しぼ) to the cow to say thank you for letting her squeeze out some fresh milk.
Context 1-EN: Can I squeeze lemon over the fried food?
Context 1-JP: <jp>レモンを唐揚げに搾ってもいいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You jump on a wave and ride around the world on it. It doesn't drop you off anywhere, until you reach a certain location: Viet<reading>nam</reading> (<jp>なみ</jp>). You jump off the wave and look at Vietnam. Imagine the most Vietnamese things you can think of to help you to make this wave-Vietnam association.
Context 1-EN: Today's waves are very high, aren't they?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の波、すごく高いね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: OMG! Koichi has been swallowed by a wave!
Context 2-JP: <jp>大へんだ！コウイチが波に飲みこまれたぞー！</jp>
Context 3-EN: The rocking of the waves to and fro feels good.
Context 3-JP: <jp>波にゆらゆら揺られるのが気持ちいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>face</kanji> of a <kanji>face</kanji> is a face, but more specifically the <vocabulary>face of a person</vocabulary>. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one).
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for 顔 isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now.

The worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally gone (がん). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the gone men (がんめん). Faces, totally gone!
Context 1-EN: Tofugu workers' facial deviation values are all very high.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員たちは、みんな顔面へんさちが高い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm suffering from facial neuralgia caused by stress.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ストレスが原因の顔面神けいつうになやまされています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hit my face hard on the asphalt.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はアスファルトに顔面を強打した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: We sell wholesale goods.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちは雑貨の卸をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>leaf</kanji> of the things you <kanji>say</kanji> is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>, though it can add up to be a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>manner of speech</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>言</jp> is one you haven't learned. It's kind of an exception, in fact, though you might see it from time to time. You'll want to imagine yourself playing a <reading>koto</reading> (<jp>こと</jp>). Each strum of the instrument sends forth several <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s from its strings, flying at the person you're talking to. You speak your <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s via music, specifically the koto (so think about using other instruments as well to communicate... they just don't work).
Context 1-EN: I'd like to hire elves if I could, but It's difficult because of the language barrier.
Context 1-JP: <jp>エルフをやといたいのは山々なんですが、言葉のかべがあるのでむずかしいんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's hard to put into words, but Koichi is a very special person to me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うまく言葉にできないけど、コウイチはわたしにとってすごく特別な人なの。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was at a loss for words.

Meaning: To Separate,To Be Divided,To Part From,To Break Up
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>separate</kanji>, so you can guess the meaning is <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember the word <jp>分ける</jp>? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from <jp>わける</jp> to <jp>わかれる</jp>. It's like we've "separated" the <jp>け</jp> and the <jp>る</jp> and combined them in the middle. <jp>け</jp>, making a <jp>かれ</jp>, which gets you to <reading><jp>わかれる</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Koichiko separated from Koichi and started going out with Viet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ子はコウイチと別れてビエトと付き合いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We broke up due to a lack of communication.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コミュニケーション不足がげんいんで別れました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I parted from her, I couldn't stop crying.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女と別れる時に、涙が止まらなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Rhythm is <jp>律動</jp>, but by adding a <jp>的</jp> in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it <vocabulary>rhythmical</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rhythmic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>律動</jp>. The <jp>的</jp> part you should also be able to read by now.
Context 1-EN: This music is very rhythmic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この音楽はとても律動的ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>丁度</jp> is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka <vocabulary>just right</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the reading for <jp>丁度</jp> you'll know the reading for this too. Your knowledge should be <vocabulary>just right</vocabulary>, as they say inside my head.
Context 1-EN: Wow! Speak of the devil!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あーっ丁度いい所に！</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's not too big or too small. It's just the right size.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大きすぎず、小さすぎず、本当に丁度いいサイズです。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>このぐらいの温度が丁度いいですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Spread out</kanji> a <kanji>needle</kanji> in a <kanji>tray</kanji> of water after rubbing it with a magnet and you'll have made a <vocabulary>compass</vocabulary>! Try it at home kids! It really works!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He was my life’s compass.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は私にとって、人生の羅針盤だったのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the verb version of <jp>保持</jp>, from two levels ago.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>保持</jp>, so if you know that word's reading, you know this one too.
Context 1-EN: Koichi retains the world record for being the fastest broccoli eater.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ブロッコリー早食い王者の世界チャンピオンの座を保持している。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In order to preserve the peace around here, we need the help of Viet's yakuza group.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この辺りの治安を保持するには、ビエトの組の力が必要だ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You should prioritize maintaining your own country’s status first.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自国の地位を保持することをまず優先した方がいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. <vocabulary> I</vocabulary> certainly like that and I bet you do too.
Context 1-EN: Leave it to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕に任せろ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was I who made the pun, "I get compensation from a doctor."
Context 2-JP: <jp>医者から慰謝料をもらうというダジャレを作ったのは僕だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: 研修 is a training or study of some kind. If it's in your current life (生) that you are doing the training, then you are a trainee. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading from <jp>研修</jp> should also help you too.
Context 1-EN: This is the new trainee, Miura.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらが、新しい研修生の三浦くんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>edit</kanji> is <jp>編集</jp>. <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does those edits is an <vocabulary>editor</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from <jp>編集</jp> should help you.
Context 1-EN: Since being designated as editor of the book, I’ve been feeling overworked.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その本の編集者として任命されてから、過労気味です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're so <kanji>mediocre</kanji> that you're <kanji>flat</kanji>. That's really <vocabulary>common</vocabulary>. Look at most of the midwest. It's really <vocabulary>mediocre</vocabulary> and flat too. And there's a whole lot of it out there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m bored with the ordinary every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>平凡な毎日に退屈していたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!
Context 1-EN: I made dried apricot jam.
Context 1-JP: <jp>干し杏のジャムを作りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Please leave this column blank.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この欄は空けておいてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>milk</kanji> <kanji>bottle</kanji> that babies use to <kanji>nurse</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>baby bottle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You disinfect the baby bottle in boiling water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>哺乳瓶を熱湯消毒しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>troublesome</kanji> (<jp>迷惑</jp>) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as <vocabulary>spam</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spam mail</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>junk mail</vocabulary>. On a more technical level it's <vocabulary>unsolicited mail</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>めいわくめーる</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>めいわくメール</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: めいわくめーる,めいわくメール
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>迷惑</jp>, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)
Context 1-EN: I get one spam mail after another.
Context 1-JP: <jp>迷惑メールが次から次へと送られてくる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I get so much spam it's driving me insane.
Context 2-JP: <jp>迷惑メールが多すぎて、精神にい常をきたしそうだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Emails from Koichi are always found in the junk mail folder. I wonder why.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチからのメールはいつも迷惑メールフォルダに入ってしまうんだけどどうしてなんだろう？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>在留</jp> is <kanji>residence</kanji>, then the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to reside</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>在留</jp> so you should be able to read this one already!
Context 1-EN: What do foreigners need when they stay in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>外国人が日本に在留する時に必要になるものは何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place you're <kanji>detain</kanji>ed is where you <kanji>exist</kanji>. As long as you're in this place, this will be your <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>. Note: mainly means "residence" in the broader sense and is parts of words like "residence card" or "foreign residents."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I became friends with an American who was residing in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本在留のアメリカ人と友達になりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In order to extend your residency, you have to leave the country and then come back.
Context 2-JP: <jp>在留期間をえん長するには、一たん国外に出ないといけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Visas and residence status are two different things.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビザと在留資格は別物です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>performance</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> allows you to be great at <vocabulary>acting</vocabulary> and doing awesome <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That actress’ acting ability is magnificent.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの女優の演技力は素晴らしい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji>! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's <vocabulary>the earth</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can not buy the Earth with money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地球はお金では買えないよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wonder what Koichi is doing right now, halfway around the globe.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは今ごろ地球のうらがわで何をしてるんだろう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Who came up with the name Earth?
Context 3-JP: <jp>地球という名前を考えたのは誰だ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When thinking about the circumstance of your current situation and the reason you're there (which is studying kanji and vocab). Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.
Context 1-EN: For some reason, the launch of this product has been cancelled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>故あって、この製品のローンチが中止になりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are many volcanoes here. For that reason, there are often earthquakes too.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ここは火山が多い。それ故に、地震もよく起きる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The mistake was down to his youth. Let's cut him some slack, shall we?
Context 3-JP: <jp>若さ故の過ちだったんだよ。大目に見てやろうじゃないか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>pupil</kanji> <kanji>hole</kanji> is still your <vocabulary>pupil</vocabulary>. It can also be called your <vocabulary>pupillary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: Can you explain when and why contraction and expansion of the pupil occurs?
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつ、どうして瞳孔の縮小と拡張が起きるのか、説明できますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>performance</kanji> <kanji>art</kanji> is a <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>entertainment</vocabulary>! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Where can I buy tickets to the performance?
Context 1-JP: <jp>演芸のチケットはどこで買えますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Take</kanji> children from their homes and <kanji>squeeze</kanji> all their talent out until they have nothing left. That's called <vocabulary>exploitation</vocabulary>, and lots of companies make money off of it. It's not very nice though.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This agent is famous for considerably exploiting his guarantees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このエージェントは、ギャラをかなり搾取することで有名だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>掲載</jp> is <kanji>publication</kanji> so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know <jp>掲載</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: The contents are way too extreme to be published.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このコンテンツは、過激すぎて掲載することはできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>cavity</kanji> (hole) is where your eye is held. This is your <vocabulary>eye socket</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It feels so good when you cover your eye sockets with a steamed towel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>蒸しタオルで眼孔を覆うと気持ち良いですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>measurement</kanji> (3.03 cm!) of <kanji>spare time</kanji>. This isn't much free time, but it's a <vocabulary>free minute</vocabulary> that you have.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My husband devotes every spare moment to working.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夫は、いつも寸暇を惜しんで働いています。</jp>

Meaning: Sun,Three Point Zero Three Centimeters,Three Centimeters,Three Point Oh Three Centimeters
Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>measurement</kanji> also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.
Context 1-EN: 1 sun is 1/10th of 1 shaku, which is approximately 3.03 centimeters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>1寸は1尺の10分の1で、約3.03センチです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Second day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day two</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
Reading Mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

The circus is in town this weekend and you can't wait to get there. You want to show off your new foots car (ふつか) to all the circus clowns. But you have to use your feet to get it there and it ends up taking you two days! Darn this old fashioned foots car!
Context 1-EN: I will go see a movie with my older sister on the second day of next month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>らい月の二日に、あねとえいがをみにいきます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's been two days since the prince followed the puppy and disappeared in the woods of Mt. Fuji.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王子が子犬をおってふじ山のじゅかいにきえてから二日がたちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you study diligently, two days is enough to learn hiragana.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ひらがななんて、しんけんにべんきょうすれば二日あれば十ぶんさ。</jp>

Meaning: To Commute,To Attend,To Go Back And Forth
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>pass through</kanji> but we already know the word <jp>通る</jp> which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say <vocabulary>to attend</vocabulary> school, or <vocabulary>to commute</vocabulary> to school.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You live in the middle of three different school districts so you need to decide which of the three schools you want to attend. You decide you don't mind that you have to commute to the farthest of the three because their mascot is Wile E. Coyote (かよ). He's your favorite Looney Toon because he always has the energy to go back and forth after that road runner.
Context 1-EN: What!? Are you going back and forth between Hokkaido and Okinawa every day?
Context 1-JP: <jp>えっ、北海道からおきなわまで毎日通ってるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi commutes to the Tofugu office on a Harley‐Davidson.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグのオフィスまでハーレーで通っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My younger sister will attend Tofugu Academy starting in April.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の妹は、四月からトーフグ学園に通うことになります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Person</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, why, that's more than one person. It's <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>! It's <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word <jp>人</jp> twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd, turning it into <jp>びと</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Why do people buy cars?
Context 1-JP: <jp>なぜ人々はくるまをかうのでしょうか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that many Papuan people can breathe underwater.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おおくのパプアニューギニアの人々は水中でもいきができるらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The people in the area are all just good natured people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このちいきの人々は、みんないい人ばかりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>little</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>young lady</vocabulary>. This word is generally used to describe someone who's between the ages of about five and eighteen.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That young lady is a famous idol.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その少女は、ゆうめいなアイドルです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A genius girl golfer has appeared for the first time in a long time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>久しぶりに、天才少女ゴルファーがあらわれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The dog and the little girl ran on the beach.
Context 3-JP: <jp>犬と少女が、はまべをかけていった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>ten thousand</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!
Context 1-EN: The plane ticket to Japan cost 105,000 yen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本へのひこうきだいは、十万五千円でした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Every year Koichi receives tens of thousands of chocolates on Valentine's Day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まいとしコウイチは、バレンタインデーに万たんいのチョコレートをもらいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The estimate on a congratulatory gift is approximately 30,000 yen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ごしゅうぎのそうばは大たい三万円です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Squeeze</kanji> an udder to get <kanji>milk</kanji>. Look at that, you're <vocabulary>milking</vocabulary> a cow!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I personally experienced milking at the farm.
Context 1-JP: <jp>牧場で搾乳体験をしてきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji>'s <kanji>shell</kanji> is called the <vocabulary>earth's crust</vocabulary>. You should have learned that in earth science. And if you didn't, at least you know now!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Japanese islands appeared after thousands of years of deformation of the Earth’s crust.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本列島は、千年に一度の大地殻変動期に突入しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>red</kanji>? Why, it's <vocabulary>red</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Could I have the red necktie?
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤いネクタイをください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This year the red nail polish is popular.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今年は赤いマニキュアがはやっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The girl wearing the red knit hat is skating.
Context 3-JP: <jp>赤いニット帽を被った女の子がスケートをしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>white</kanji>? <vocabulary>White</vocabulary>, of course!
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the vocab <jp>白</jp> you learned, so you already know the reading. Go you!
Context 1-EN: There was white snow falling outside.
Context 1-JP: <jp>外では、白いゆきがふっていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our black cows are more energetic than the white ones.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの牛は白いのよりもくろいのの方が元気がいい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A fluffy, white rabbit was hopping in the field.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フワフワで白いウサギが野原でピョンピョン跳ねていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Mix <kanji>sulfur</kanji> and <kanji>acid</kanji> and you'll get <vocabulary>sulfuric acid</vocabulary>! That's how science works! How simple!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Where did you get your hands on some sulfuric acid?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どこで硫酸を手に入れたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>early</kanji>. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something <vocabulary>early</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>quickly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word <jp>早い</jp>, you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: Why did you go to school early yesterday?
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのうはどうして早く学校に行きましたか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please get plenty of rest and feel better soon!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ゆっくり休んで早くよくなってください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>near</kanji>. So it also means <vocabulary>near</vocabulary>, or in the <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned <jp>近い</jp>, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m currently living with my sister near the school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は、学校の近くに、姉とすんでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Seen close up, that teen idol is not pretty at all, huh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのアイドル、近くで見るとあんまりかわいくないね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t you want to have a drink at the yakitori shop nearby?
Context 3-JP: <jp>近くの焼き鳥屋で、一杯ひっかけていかないか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>お</jp> is added to elevate someone in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. What do you call someone in front of you? That's right, <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>. Over time, this word has lost its sense of politeness, and nowadays it sounds very rough and often rude. This "you" is a good way to show anger, and some people also use it in very casual situations to show affection.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>前</jp> is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word <jp>前</jp>. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: I want to live my whole life with you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一生お前といっしょに生きていきたいんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I really hate men who call women "you."
Context 2-JP: <jp>女のことお前ってよぶ男本当にきらいだわ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The gyoza you make is really tasty.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前の作る餃子は本当に美味しいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is used as a <kanji>substitute</kanji> for an <kanji>island</kanji>. Which island is it? That's right, <vocabulary>Tashirojima</vocabulary>. Imagine a rice paddy in the middle of the sea, standing in for <vocabulary>Tashiro Island</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned this particular kun'yomi for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

When you go to Tashirojima, make sure you visit the old woman. You know what woman I'm talking about, the one who starred on Murder she wrote (しろ). She writes a lot about cats now, I guess.
Context 1-EN: The population of Tashirojima is less than one hundred.
Context 1-JP: <jp>田代島の人口は百人以下です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are no gas stations on Tashirojima.
Context 2-JP: <jp>田代島にはガソリンスタンドがありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The most famous "cat island" is Tashiro Island in Japan's Miyagi prefecture.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最も有名な「猫島」といえば、日本の宮城県にある田代島という島です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Part</kanji> of a <kanji>part</kanji>? That's a <vocabulary>portion</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>section</vocabulary> of that part, and even a <vocabulary>part</vocabulary> in itself!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: What color do you want for this part?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この部分は、何色にしますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: What was the front part of the brain again?
Context 2-JP: <jp>のうの前の部分の名前って何だっけ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The movie was full of parts I sympathized with and I cried all over myself.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この映画、共感出来る部分だらけでめちゃくちゃ泣けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>express</kanji> a <kanji>feeling</kanji> it shows on your face. This is called a <vocabulary>facial expression</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please don't make such a scary facial expression.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そんなこわい表情をしないでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After looking at WaniKani's revenue report, Koichi's face looked very happy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニの売り上げレポートを見たコウイチの表情はとてもうれしそうだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The children’s faces all looked very lively.
Context 3-JP: <jp>子供達の表情は、みんなとても活き活きとしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: We must not forgive sex crimes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>性はんざいをゆるしてはいけません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think it's important to consider gender equality in order to understand actual gender differences.
Context 2-JP: <jp>性による違いをはあくしたうえで、男女平どうを考えることが大事だと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please mark whether you are a man, woman, or other under gender.
Context 3-JP: <jp>性のところの、男性、女性、その他のいずれかにチェックをしてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>move</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is the same reading you learned from the word <jp>動く</jp>. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!
Context 1-EN: If you want to know about drug-related yakuza activities, you should go talk to Viet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヤクザのまやくがらみの動きが知りたいなら、ビエトと話をしに行ったらいいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi and Viet are learning how to monitor market trends this week.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチとビエトは、今週は市場の動きのかんさつ方ほうを学んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That person’s movements are a little unnatural.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの人、何だか動きが不自然ですね。</jp>

Meaning: To Look Back At,To Triumph Over
Meaning Mnemonic: When you want to <kanji>see</kanji> something one more time before you have to <kanji>return</kanji> it, you need <vocabulary>to look back at</vocabulary> it. It might be your last chance to look at it, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are from the words <jp>見</jp> and <jp>返す</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: I will be the Tofugu president and show Koichi, who looked down on me, what I can do.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの社長になって、コウイチを見返してやるぞ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I gave the kitten some sardines, she looked back at me with a face that was like, "Is this really for me?!" and it was super cute.
Context 2-JP: <jp>子猫にイワシをあげたら、「本当にいいの？」って感じの顔でマジマジと見返してきたのがマジかわいかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You should look back over your test before you submit it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>答案は提出する前に見返したほうがいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The true commander of the Tofugu army is not Koichi, but Viet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグ軍のしんの指きかんはコウイチじゃなくてビエトだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How could we evade the enemy troops' pursuit?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうやっててき軍の追げきをかわせばいいんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s go back to the army base for now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>とりあえず軍の拠点に戻ってみましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: That soldier threw donuts at helpless children!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの兵が、無力な子供たちにドーナツを投げつけたんだ！</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>たくさんの兵たちが、梅毒に苦しんでいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The American army frequently gathers here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここで、アメリカ兵たちがよく屯しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
You've learned the がわ as the reading for this kanji, but when its used on its own as a vocabulary word, it is read as そば. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Having a sober(そば) person by your side is important when you're drunk.

Think of other vocabulary words that use がわ. In these words, 側 is a suffix, so it will have another kanji that comes before it.
Context 1-EN: Can I stay by your side a little longer?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう少しだけ、側にいてもいい？</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>お母さんの側をはなれちゃだめよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm thinking about putting a potted plant by the side of the sofa.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ソファの側に植木を置こうかなと思ってるの。</jp>

Meaning: On The Brink,On The Verge,Just In Front Of,Just Before
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Before</kanji> you take the last <kanji>measurement</kanji>, you know you're <vocabulary>on the brink</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: My company is on the verge of bankruptcy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の会社は破産寸前である。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>behind</kanji> your <kanji>back</kanji> is in the <vocabulary>background</vocabulary>. It's also probably plotting against you, <vocabulary>behind the scenes</vocabulary>. Sneaky, sneaky.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: I completely didn’t notice the enemy lurking in the background.
Context 1-JP: <jp>背後に敵が潜んでいたことに全く気づかなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Koichi bought an airplane as a strategy for reducing his taxes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは節ぜい対さくのために、飛行機を一機こう入しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Time is ripe for Koichi to be the president of the United States.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチがアメリカ合しゅう国の大とうりょうになる機はじゅくしました。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>今はまだ、機を窺っているんだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Let Go,To Set Free,To Let Escape
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>逃げる</jp> means "to escape"? Well this verbs means <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to set free</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to let escape</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる.

If you have trouble telling the two words apart, remember that if you're going to let go of someone, make sure they have their knee guards (にが). It's a dangerous world, you can't have them running free without some extra protection, you know.
Context 1-EN: We can’t let the criminal escape.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの犯人を逃がすことはできない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've infiltrated this facility to set free the hostages who are being held here.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この施設に捕らえられている人質を逃がすために潜入しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He was a real stitting duck, but we let him go.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いいカモだったのに、逃しちゃったね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When an <kanji>author</kanji> <kanji>appear</kanji>s in public it's always <vocabulary>remarkable</vocabulary>. People usually don't remember there's anyone behind those pages, so when the actual author shows up in person it's pretty <vocabulary>striking</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our company’s results are making a remarkable recovery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我が社の業績は顕著に回復しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> of <kanji>industry</kanji> makes a lot of things by hand, so everything they make is <vocabulary>artificial</vocabulary>, and also means it's <vocabulary>man made</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is your brain really artificial?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたののうは、ほんとうに人工ののうなんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I put artificial turf in the garden.
Context 3-JP: <jp>にわに人工しばをしいてみました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Third day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day three</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, are an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 三 from when you learned the word 三つ. Here is a way to remember the reading for 日:

On the third day you have to give me (み) a ride in your car (か). I don't have a car of my own, so don't forget me, okay?
Context 1-EN: Where did those two people meet on the third, two months ago?
Context 1-JP: <jp>二人は、せんせん月の三日にどこであいましたか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I haven't had water for three days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>三日も水をのんでいません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The third day of March is Girl’s Day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>三月三日はひなまつりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you often <kanji>think</kanji> about <kanji>study</kanji>ing <kanji>old</kanji> things, it's called <vocabulary>archeology</vocabulary>. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m interested in Japanese archeology.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、日本の考古学にきょうみがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm going to quit this archeology job at the end of the month.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今月末でこの考古学のしごとをやめるんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You can study archeology at this university.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この大学では、考古学を学べます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Say <kanji>furthermore</kanji> <kanji>again</kanji> and you'll be saying it <vocabulary>all the more</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I came to dislike you all the more.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのことが尚更嫌いになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is <vocabulary>every morning</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: I take a shower every morning
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎朝、シャワーをあびます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I had a really great time with you every morning. Thank you so much.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎朝、本当に楽しかったです。ありがとうございました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I do radio exercises every morning.

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>teach</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>teaching</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned <jp>教える</jp>, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: You keep my father’s teachings alive and well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたは、父さんの教えをしっかりまもって生きるのよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's such a great lesson, isn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>それはすばらしい教えですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I follow your teachings nothing goes well.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君の教えに従うと、ろくなことがない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>自由</jp> means freedom? Well when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it causes you <vocabulary>discomfort</vocabulary> and really <vocabulary>inconveniences</vocabulary> you. That not is in the way of your freedom.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You’ve been living in such comfort. You shouldn’t ask for too much.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何不自由ない生活をしてるくせに、ぜいたくだよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is priority seating for the elderly and disabled, okay?
Context 2-JP: <jp>このせきは、お年よりや体の不自由な方のためのゆう先ざせきですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My older brother’s legs are disabled.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle finger</vocabulary>, of course! And because we don't see the difference, it's your <vocabulary>middle toe</vocabulary> too. Stick that up the next time someone makes you mad.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
Context 1-EN: A stray dog bit my second finger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>の良犬に中指をかまれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My callus on the middle finger on my right hand is getting pretty hard.
Context 2-JP: <jp>右手の中指に出来たタコが、かなりかたくなってきてます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t stick out your middle finger!

Meaning Mnemonic:
Okay, so this is a stretch but stay with me! In addition to your family name, the first thing you need to learn as a child is how to understand centigrade. If you can't tell what temperature it is outside, or in your house, or in your body to tell if you're sick, you won't do so well with this living thing. So when you think back to the first things you learned in addition to your own family name, think centigrade!

Of course, in reality, these kanji were simply chosen for their pronunciation rather than their meaning, but hopefully that mnemonic will help you remember which kanji are used here!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today’s maximum temperature is twenty-five degrees Celsius.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の最高気温は、摂氏二十五度です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: 100 degrees Celsius is the boiling point of water.
Context 3-EN: I wish the US would hurry up and change from Fahrenheit to Celsius.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカも早く華氏から摂氏に変えればいいのに。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>woman</kanji> who is also a <kanji>god</kanji> is a <vocabulary>goddess</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 女 yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

This goddess has the most beautiful 目 (め) you've ever seen. You can't stop staring into them. This must be how people know they've met a god.
Context 1-EN: Can you cut this goddess doll's bangs kinda short?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この女神の人形の前がみを少し短くしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My jaw dropped from the female deity's selfish attitude.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの女神の身勝手さには、開いた口がふさがらなかったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I came across a beautiful woman’s voice that sounded like a goddess’.
Context 3-JP: <jp>女神のように美しい女声に出会った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some things happen outside of <kanji>reason</kanji>. They happen <kanji>in addition</kanji> to it. That's called <vocabulary>divine providence</vocabulary>. You can't explain it, but something outside of reason definitely influenced the things around you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: No one can defy the laws of nature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰も自然の摂理には逆らえないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some <kanji>day</kanji>s are so special that you have to <kanji>write down</kanji> all your <kanji>thoughts</kanji> when they're done. These are special days like <vocabulary>holidays</vocabulary> and your <vocabulary>anniversary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because <jp>ひ</jp> is rendaku'd into <jp>び</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Forgetting something like a Memorial Day is the worst!
Context 1-JP: <jp>記念日をわすれるなんて、最低よ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband gave me a fully automatic washing machine for our wedding anniversary this year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今年のけっこん記念日には、夫から全自動せんたくきをもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On Independence Day, I'm selling clothes at a flea market.
Context 3-JP: <jp>どく立記念日は、フリマで服を売っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>動物</jp> means animal? Well when you add <kanji>park</kanji> it becomes a <vocabulary>zoo</vocabulary>. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Even yakuza can come to the zoo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヤクザだって動物園に来ることもあるさ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The flamingos looked so beautiful when I saw them up close at a zoological garden.
Context 2-JP: <jp>動物園で間近で見たフラミンゴは、とてもきれいでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Many koala bears have an innate virus called koala retrovirus and it often causes a life-threatening diseases like lymphoma when they get stressed out, so please make sure not to use your camera's flash or speak loudly when you go to the menagerie.
Context 3-JP: <jp>多くのコアラはコアラレトロウィルスというウイルスを先天的に保持しており、ストレスなどを受けると、リンパ腫など死につながる病気を発症してしまいます。ですので、動物園に行かれた際は、カメラのフラッシュや大声を出すなどしないよう、十分気をつけてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your body <kanji>take</kanji>s nutrients into itself <kanji>in addition</kanji> to all the extra crap you eat. It's called your daily <vocabulary>intake</vocabulary>. And it gets all of those nutrients in your body through <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I calculated my calorie intake for one day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一日の摂取カロリーを計算してみました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>nothing</kanji>, so when you have nothing, you are <vocabulary>without</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you are without you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up gnashing (なし) your teeth together instead.
Context 1-EN: These grapes are seedless, so they are easy to eat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このブドウはたね無しだから食べやすいですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was, without a doubt, the perfect speech.
Context 2-JP: <jp>文く無しのす晴らしいスピーチだったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you cancel this deal for now?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この話は、一旦無しにしてもらえますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>announce</kanji> something to <kanji>warn</kanji> somebody, you're <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary> them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I advised him that he should pay back money he borrowed soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>借りた金を早く返すよう警告した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That player gets a yellow card warning in every game.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの選手はどの試合でも必ず警告のイエローカードを出されるね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you intend to ignore this warning?
Context 3-JP: <jp>警告を無視するつもりなのか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you can <kanji>exist</kanji> all by your<kanji>self</kanji>, then you can do things <vocabulary>freely</vocabulary> as you please.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi always surprises people with his very flexible ideas.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、自由自在な発想でいつもみんなをおどろかせてくれます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm looking for an adjustable leash for dogs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しんしゅく自在の犬用リードを探しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That man can manipulate minds at will.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの男は、他人の心を自在に操れる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>機嫌</jp> means mood? Well when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it becomes a <vocabulary>bad mood</vocabulary>. It's so bad it's like you have no mood at all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Hanae is in a bad mood right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>花江は今、不機嫌なのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Cloth</kanji> from the <kanji>earth</kanji> is still <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary>, just a little dirty.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, you've learned them both already!
Context 1-EN: I stitched lace into cloth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レースを布地にたたきつけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>perform</kanji> <kanji>above</kanji> the stage it's a <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>. This word is usually used for musical and theatrical performances.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can you tell me the time of the Lion King performance?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ライオンキングの上演時間を教えて下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>catch</kanji> a <kanji>whale</kanji> you're <vocabulary>whaling</vocabulary>, and that's illegal now so you should probably put the whale back.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m against whaling.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は捕鯨には反対です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> of the <kanji>amount</kanji> is your <vocabulary>total</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please pay the total amount for the candy yourself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お菓子代は、全額自己負担でお願いします。</jp>

Meaning: To Look Out Over,To Survey,To Sweep,To Glance Over,To Take An Extensive View Of
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji mean <kanji>see</kanji> and <kanji>transit</kanji>, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going <vocabulary>to look out over</vocabulary> everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The sunflower field went on as far as the eye could see.
Context 1-JP: <jp>見渡す限り、向日葵畑が続いていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>obey</kanji> <kanji>orders</kanji> people consider you to be an <vocabulary>obedient</vocabulary> person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He’s as obedient as a dog.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは犬のように従順だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something <kanji>big</kanji> in <kanji>width</kanji> is still <vocabulary>big</vocabulary>, in fact it's of a pretty <vocabulary>substantial</vocabulary> size.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The meeting’s documents were largely changed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会議の資料が大幅に変更されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A room that comes <kanji>alive</kanji> in <kanji>interval</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>living room</vocabulary>. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes. This word is usually used for western style living rooms by the way, so don't mistake it for a traditional Japanese one.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Dad is watching TV in the living room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は居間でテレビを観ています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>approach</kanji> to <kanji>give</kanji> something, you are probably giving a <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Did you know that Tofugu is contributing to world peace?
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguが世界平和に寄与していることを知っているかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji> isn't your own father, but he is the chief of your father. He's your father's older brother, who has always owned your father. He's your <vocabulary>uncle</vocabulary>. This word can be used for your mother's brother too, but in both cases he has to be the older brother, not younger.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception, at least the 父 part is, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Your uncle is a very religious man, he is the chief, after all. Whenever you see him he's always shouting, "Oh Jesus! (おじ)" at the sky. Your uncle and Jesus are pretty close.
Context 1-EN: My uncle is a banker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伯父は銀行員です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The edge of the cheese is what we call the fool (ふ) cheese (ち) because nobody wants that part.
Context 1-EN: Do you have any rimless glasses?
Context 1-JP: <jp>縁が無い眼鏡はありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If your <kanji>interior</kanji> is <kanji>deep</kanji>, then you're a really <vocabulary>profound</vocabulary> person.
Reading Whitelist: おくぶかい,おくふかい
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned <jp>おく</jp> when you learned the kanji, and <jp>ふかい</jp> from <jp>深い</jp>, so you should be able to read this on your own. Most of the time the <jp>ふ</jp> is rendaku'd into <jp>ぶ</jp>, but it can be read the other way too.
Context 1-EN: A hunter is a very profound occupation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>狩人とは非常に奥深い職業です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>king</vocabulary>, just of a bigger area.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That king is very greedy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの国王は、とてもよくばりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm starting to understand the king.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは、国王のことをじょじょにりかいしてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I became the king as a youth of 18.
Context 3-JP: <jp>18歳という若さで国王になった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> is all you get. It's your <vocabulary>whole life</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>all through life</vocabulary>, and when it's used as an adjective it means <vocabulary>lifelong</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who has been in charge of you your whole life? The shogun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your entire life.
Context 1-EN: I will treasure this ring my entire life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このゆびわは、一生、大切にします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My father remained single all his life.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの父は、しぬまで一生どくしんでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll make up for it with my life.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Venus</vocabulary>. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What you see over there is Venus.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこに見えているのは、金星です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do they have Sports Day in the school on Venus?
Context 2-JP: <jp>金星の学こうには、うんどう会はありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Someday humans will migrate to Venus.
Context 3-JP: <jp>人類はいつか金星に移住することになるだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I looked at the figures of those children and I felt like my own wisdom was freed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そんな子供の姿を見て、智を開く思いがしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When someone <kanji>quit</kanji>s living you need to offer your <kanji>condolence</kanji>s during their <vocabulary>memorial address</vocabulary>. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who will read the funeral address?
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰が弔辞を読むのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>boat</kanji>'s <kanji>body</kanji> is called the <vocabulary>hull</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who graffitied the hull?
Context 1-JP: <jp>船体にらくがきをしたのはだれだ！？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The kraken smashed its tentacles through the ship's hull.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クラーケンがしょく手で船体をつきやぶったんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The hull was bigger than I thought.
Context 3-JP: <jp>船体は思った以上に大きかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> carries your <vocabulary>water supply</vocabulary>. In the old days, these were called <vocabulary>aqueduct</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This tap water is safe to drink.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この水道の水は、のんでも平気ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I couldn't pay the water bill, so my water was shut off.
Context 2-JP: <jp>水道代がはらえなかったので、水道が止められてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>水道が凍結してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you try to <kanji>see</kanji> a bunch of <kanji>thing</kanji>s at once, you are probably <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read <jp>物</jp>. <jp>見</jp>'s on'yomi (<jp>けん</jp>) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with <jp>発見</jp> a couple levels ago, so that should help. Just imagine taking the samurai <reading>Ken</reading> on an epic <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary> trip. Think of all the things you and Ken will visit!
Context 1-EN: It seems fun, so let’s have a look.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おも白そうだから、見物してみましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We watched the Christmas parade from the office windows.
Context 2-JP: <jp>オフィスのまどから、クリスマスパレードを見物しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mom would have gone sightseeing in Tokyo.
Context 3-JP: <jp>母ちゃんなら、東京見物に出かけたぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: You can’t wear swimsuits on this island's beaches.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この島のはま辺では、水着は着用できません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My wife is the most beautiful woman on this island.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの家内は、この島で一番の美人です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to have you live on this island for a week.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この島で一週間生活をしてもらいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: How can you solve your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji>? With a little extra <vocabulary>schooling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>learning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Scholarship is always associated with literature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学問と文学は切っても切れない関係にある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I personally think that universities aren't a place to learn, but a place to obtain the qualifications of a "university degree."
Context 2-JP: <jp>こ人てきには、大学って学問する所じゃなくて、「大そつ」っていうしかくを取りに行くための所だと思ってるんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You must not neglect your studies.
Context 3-JP: <jp>学問を疎かにしてはいけない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You need to know the <kanji>word</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>s of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good <vocabulary>dictionary</vocabulary> that can explain its <vocabulary>lexicon</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can you put the dictionary back in the box after you use it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その辞典、使い終わったらちゃんと箱の中にもどしておいてね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: An electronic dictionary has various dictionaries in it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>電子辞書には色んな辞典が入っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t know how to use a dictionary.
Context 3-JP: <jp>辞典の使い方が分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>brushwood</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Shiba Inu</vocabulary>. They're the same pretty orange color as brushwood trees, so that's how they got their name.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Nikka isn’t a Shiba, she’s a Jindo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ニッカは柴犬ではなく珍島犬です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>nothing</kanji> to <kanji>say</kanji> you sit in <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 言 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Nothing cuts through silence like a gong (ごん). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.
Context 1-EN: Every night I get a silent prank phone call.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎晩無言電話がかかってくるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu workers seem to work silently, but they are actually chatting on an app called Slack.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員たちは、無言でもくもくと仕事をしているように見えますが、実はスラックというアプリでチャットしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Suddenly, some random guy started lecturing me about how mothers feel affection for their children, and it freaked me out so much I went completely silent.
Context 3-JP: <jp>知らないオッサンから急に母親ってのは自分の子どもに愛情を感じるものだろうとか説教されてさぁ、びっくりして無言になっちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Attain,To Reach,To Get To,To Arrive At
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>達</jp> means <kanji>attain</kanji>. So, when you add <jp>する</jp> to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to attain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for <jp>達</jp> is <jp>たつ</jp>, but here it's shortened, to just <jp>たっ</jp>. So make sure you remember.
Context 1-EN: We were a little bit late, but we arrived safely at our destination.
Context 1-JP: <jp>少しおくれたが、無事に目的地に達した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's beard finally reached his waist.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのひげは、ついにこしまで達した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Only a little longer until we attain the target number of people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>目標人数に達するまで、あと少しだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> in Japan is called the <vocabulary>Diet</vocabulary>. It's their version of <vocabulary>congress</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They are trying to obstruct the proceedings of Parliament by any means necessary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつら、何とかして議会の進行を妨害するつもりだぞ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: To be honest, it's extremely troublesome having to explain it at Congress.
Context 2-JP: <jp>正直、そのことについて議会で説明するのはかなり面倒です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Diet has already come to a decision.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もう議会で決定したことなんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>part of speech</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> spits out <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary>es. It's all the machine is programmed to do.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

The only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (せりふ).
Context 1-EN: You remember these long speeches well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな長い台詞、よく覚えられるわね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>規則</jp> and <jp>正しい</jp>, that you learned already. If you follow the correct rules everything will stay <vocabulary>regular</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well regulated</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>規則</jp> and <jp>正しい</jp>, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.
Context 1-EN: Please live a regular life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>規則正しい生活を送って下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The person who <kanji>govern</kanji>s your <kanji>house</kanji> like a <kanji>wife</kanji> is your <vocabulary>housekeeper</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think we should hire a housekeeper.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家政婦を雇おうかと思っているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>approach</kanji> a building and <kanji>attach</kanji> some stuff to it, you're making a <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>. They get to keep it, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I contribute a little money to my alma mater every year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎年少しだけ、母校へお金を寄付しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> only <kanji>lay</kanji>s down when she's about to <vocabulary>ambush</vocabulary> the enemy! If you see some soldiers laying around, it's not that they're lazy, it's because they're getting ready to pounce!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They were attacked by an ambush.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伏兵に襲われたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>decorate</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>decoration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: It's about time we started preparations for the New Year’s decorations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そろそろ正月飾りの準備をしておかなくちゃ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

People think you're dancing, but you're really jumping from the mice (まい) running on your floor. You don't want the mice running up your legs so you have to hop from one to the other, making it look like you're dancing.
Context 1-EN: This is Japan’s oldest dance.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、日本最古の舞です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>flood</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> still makes a <vocabulary>flood</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. But watch out because <jp>すい</jp> becomes <jp>ずい</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: The river overflowed from the typhoon and became a flood.
Context 1-JP: <jp>台風で川が氾濫し、洪水になりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Make</kanji> something <kanji>excellent</kanji> and everyone will call it a <vocabulary>fine work</vocabulary>. Or make something that sucks and let everyone down. It's your call.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The picture I drew was chosen as a good piece of work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の描いた絵が佳作で入選しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>still</kanji> need more time to finish a project and you tell whoever is in charge <kanji>beforehand</kanji> you'll be able to get an <vocabulary>extension</vocabulary>. Then you'll be able to finish it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I suppose I’ll give you a three day extension.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前に三日間の猶予を与えてやろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word share one of the same meanings: <vocabulary>form</vocabulary>. It doesn't just mean form though, it means <vocabulary>tense</vocabulary> too. Like verb tense.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: When you talk using desu and masu forms you sound polite.
Context 1-JP: <jp>です・ます形ではなしをするとていねいにきこえます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A person who starts conversations with negative form sentences is likely to have some difficulties in communicating with others.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ひてい形から会わに入る人はコミュしょうのかのうせいがたかい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why did you just say that in past tense?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして今、過去形で言ったの？</jp>
