Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Saturn</vocabulary>. That's why it's called "sat"urn. Because the first people to find it sat on the ground there. It's a star made completely of sit-on-able ground.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you know which one is Saturn?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どれが土星か、分かりますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How can I get to Saturn?
Context 2-JP: <jp>土星にはどうやって行けばいいですか？</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は土星出身の宇宙人です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned that <jp>三角</jp> means "triangle." Well this means <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary> too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
Reading: <reading><jp>さんかくけい</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>さんかっけい</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: さんかくけい,さんかっけい
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Reading Audio Male: [sound:Vocab-さんかくけい-Male.mp3],[sound:Vocab-さんかっけい-Male.mp3]
Reading Audio Female: [sound:Vocab-さんかくけい-Female.mp3],[sound:Vocab-さんかっけい-Female.mp3]
Context 1-EN: How do you make onigiri into a triangle?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうすれば、三角形のオニギリをにぎれるんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: A big triangle, consisting of three magnitude stars from Lyra, Aquila, and Cygnus, stretches out in the summer night sky.
Context 2-JP: <jp>夏の夜空には、天の川をはさんでことざとわしざと白鳥ざの一とう星をむすんだ大三角形が広がります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is a triangle park there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そこには、三角形の公園があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>write down</kanji> a lot of stuff focusing on one <kanji>thing</kanji> it's called an <vocabulary>article</vocabulary>. If it's on something that just happened it will probably be a <vocabulary>news story</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I wrote an article about American education.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、アメリカの教いくについて、記事をかきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kristen, I've just found your article in this month's National Geographic magazine!
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリスティンの記事、今月号のナショナル・ジオグラフィックで見たよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place you <kanji>wait</kanji> to <kanji>join</kanji> other people is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>meeting place</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. <jp>待ち</jp> → <jp>待</jp>, <jp>合い</jp> → <jp>合</jp> and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!
Context 1-EN: Start squatting in the meeting place on my signal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>合図をしたら、待合でスクワットを始めてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The waiting room was so cold that I got a bladder infection.
Context 2-JP: <jp>待合する場所がさむすぎて、ぼうこうえんになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I ran into a friend from a long time ago in the waiting room of the hospital and we chatted about the old days.
Context 3-JP: <jp>病院の待合でばったり久しぶりに友人に会って、昔話に花がさきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>gather</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>gathering</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: There’s a get-together with people from the lab today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は研究室の集まりがある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Not many people showed up at today's drinking party and it was also very disorganized, eh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんか今日の飲み会、集まりも悪かったし、グダグダだったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My younger brother brought his girlfriend to our New Year's gathering.
Context 3-JP: <jp>正月の集まりに弟が彼女を連れてきやがった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

You notice a lot of neglect when it comes to old road soap cars (おろそか). If you drive down the old road you'll see neglected cars made of soap all over the place. It's sad, really.
Context 1-EN: You must not neglect the basics.
Context 1-JP: <jp>基本を疎かにしてはいけません。</jp>

Meaning: Far Away,Distant,At A Distance,Distant Place,By Far
Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun/no-adjective version of the kanji <kanji>far</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>distant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading which you learned with <jp>遠い</jp>. How convenient!
Context 1-EN: I'm not wearing glasses right now, so I can't see far away objects very well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今はめがねをかけてないので、遠くの物がよく見えません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I live far away from my family.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私は、家族から、遠くはなれて住んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A gunshot went off in a far off direction.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>discussion</kanji>s is known as a <vocabulary>conference room</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi hurried to the conference room to help Viet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ビエトを助けるために、会議室まで飛んで行きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet and Koichi went in the meeting room and still haven't come out.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトとコウイチが会議室に入ったまんまずっと出てこないんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m staying in the conference room now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今は会議室で寝泊まりしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you are <kanji>high</kanji>er than <kanji>equal</kanji>, you are above the very top, you are above everyone. You are <vocabulary>high class</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You have an extraordinarily high class technique like that, huh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ずい分高等な技術を持っているんだね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My son is still an elementary school kid, but he is studying high grade mathematics at a cram school.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの息子はまだ小学生ですが、じゅくではすでに高等の数学を勉強しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please tell me about higher education in your country.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの国の高等教育について教えて下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>song</kanji> you sing to <kanji>protect</kanji> your <kanji>child</kanji> while they sleep is called a <vocabulary>lullaby</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 守 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you finish singing a lullaby to your child they always ask for more (もり). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.
Context 1-EN: Kristen's lullaby has reached the professional level.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クリステンの子守歌は、プロのいきに達している。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What's the most popular lullaby in America?
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカで一番有名な子守歌は何ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: It's a lullaby that was sung for me when I was little.
Context 3-JP: <jp>子供の頃に歌ってもらった子守歌なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What does your <kanji>heart</kanji> want to <kanji>acquire</kanji> above all other things? <vocabulary>Knowledge</vocabulary>! That's why you're here isn't it? Dig deep and see that all your heart wants is more <vocabulary>information</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> of Japanese to be happy.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My senpai passed on his knowledge about job hunting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先輩が就職活動の心得を教えてくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You look down and you've sprouted a tail! You're so shocked that all you can say is "Oh. (お) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.
Context 1-EN: Koichi can look at a fish's tail and tell you what kind it is based on that alone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、魚の尾を見ただけで魚の種類を言うのが特技です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Without tails, birds would have difficulty landing.
Context 2-JP: <jp>尾が無いと、鳥は上手く着りく出来ません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why do you think the custom of shortening dog’s tails started?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして犬の尾を短くする習慣が産まれたのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Bad</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you <kanji>dislike</kanji> are <vocabulary>unpleasant feelings</vocabulary>. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!
Context 1-EN: I’m always filled with disgust when I talk with you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたと話していると、いつも嫌悪感を抱くのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you want to use your <kanji>finger</kanji> to explain the <kanji>distinction</kanji> between more than one thing you need <vocabulary>to point at</vocabulary> it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s rude to point at people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人を指差すのは失礼だよ。</jp>

Meaning: No Sense Of Direction,Bad Sense Of Direction
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>方向</jp> and <jp>音痴</jp>. When your sense of direction is tone-deaf, it means you have <vocabulary>no sense of direction</vocabulary>. You get lost no matter how hard you try.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have no sense of direction so I get lost immediately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は方向音痴で、すぐ道に迷います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>規則</jp> means "rule" or "regulation." So a <kanji>not</kanji> "rule" or "regulation" is an <vocabulary>irregularity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My health was ruined by my disorderly life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不規則な生活で体調を崩してしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When one person is in a position to <kanji>judge</kanji> everyone <kanji>alone</kanji> by themselves, they're definitely a part of a <vocabulary>dictatorship</vocabulary>. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ll become the best dictator in the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は世界一の独裁者になるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Combine a <kanji>grave</kanji> and a <kanji>tombstone</kanji> and you make a <vocabulary>gravestone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Someone knocked over the gravestone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かが墓碑を倒したんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is both <kanji>pleasant</kanji> and <kanji>suitable</kanji> is still really <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Life with an air conditioner is pleasant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>エアコンのある生活は快適だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>fear</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>fear</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: I’m afraid there will be a landslide.
Context 1-JP: <jp>土砂崩れの恐れがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>mistake</kanji>, so it means a <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> or if it's on a computer, an <vocabulary>error</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you make a mistake, you need to admit to it. When someone asks, "Who's responsible for this mistake?" You say, "I am (あやま)."
Context 1-EN: I finally noticed my mistakes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ようやく誤りに気がついた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>, then you're most likely <vocabulary>underwater</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It can only be used underwater.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水中でしか使えない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I looked to the right, there was an underwater world in front of me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>右をみると、水中のせかいがひろがっていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t open my eyes underwater.
Context 3-JP: <jp>水中でめをあけることができません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You want to <kanji>mix</kanji> opinions from <kanji>outside</kanji> your country into the way you handle things. That's called <vocabulary>diplomacy</vocabulary>. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We discussed Japanese diplomacy today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、日本の外交についてはなしあいをしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We have a shortage of diplomats.
Context 3-EN: Japan isn’t very good at diplomacy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本は外交があまり上手ではない。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Transparent,To Be Clear,To Be See Through
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>透ける</jp> and <jp>通る</jp>. When you are transparent enough to pass through other things, you're still going <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary> and people will be able <vocabulary>to see through you</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Her hand was so white it was almost transparent.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の手は透き通るほど白かった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If there is <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>wicked</kanji> about your <kanji>spirit</kanji> at all, you are a going to be an <vocabulary>innocent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>simple minded</vocabulary> person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The children laughed innocently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供達は無邪気に笑い合っていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you control your <kanji>hand</kanji> an <kanji>approximate</kanji> amount, you are going to be a very <vocabulary>moderate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reasonable</vocabulary> person.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is a reasonable price, isn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>手頃な値段ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>ground</kanji>, then you're most likely <vocabulary>underground</vocabulary>. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Underground it’s warm in the winter and cold in the summer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地中は、冬にはあたたかく、なつはつめたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Many of the lakes are connected by subterranean channels.
Context 2-JP: <jp>多くのみずうみは、地中の水ろでつながっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What do I need to do to gauge the temperature underground?
Context 3-JP: <jp>地中の温度を測るにはどうすればいいですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
What do you use to show that a word is lively? Conjugation! Lively things are happening, so you have to conjugate your words to match.

It also has another meaning. When you want to actually use something lively you are making practical use of it. I mean, you're using it, after all. So as long as you aren't pretending to use it, it's probably practical.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today we will learn verb conjugation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、どうしの活用をべんきょうします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I make use of small pockets of time and study Japanese on WaniKani.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ちょこっとあいたじかんを活用して、ワニカニで日本ごをべんきょうします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t know if I can put this data to good use.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このデータをうまく活用して、何かできないかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Is there a hotel around there?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その辺に、ホテルはありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They have very heavy snowfall in that region.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの辺はごう雪地たいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm going to end it here for today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日はこの辺で、終わりにします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have to find the right <kanji>tool</kanji> to <kanji>suit</kanji> your <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary>. If you have a <vocabulary>health</vocabulary> condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for <jp>具</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>合</jp>. You've learned them both, so you should be able to read this word too!
Context 1-EN: My mother’s condition isn’t very good.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母の具合があまりよくないんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You don't look great at all. Are you okay?
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんかめっちゃ具合わるそうだけど、大じょうぶ?</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was a little under the weather yesterday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと昨日から具合が良くなくて。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fire</kanji> is a <kanji>thing</kanji> that makes more <vocabulary>fire</vocabulary>. Basically fire is fire.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The fire was on the fifth floor of the apartment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>火事があった場所は、アパートの五かいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I smell something strange! Maybe a fire?
Context 2-JP: <jp>何か臭うんだけど。もしかして、火事じゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yesterday I had a dream that my house caught on fire.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日、家が火事になる夢を見たんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tombstone</kanji> made of a big <kanji>stone</kanji> is used as a <vocabulary>stone monument</vocabulary>. These stones are usually so big that they're used for multiple people who died together.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A stone monument was built at the site where the height of the tsunami hit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>津波が襲った高さの地点に石碑が建てられているのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I saw Koichi walking with a different girl.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチが、別の女と歩いているところを見たの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This and that are two different stories.
Context 2-JP: <jp>それとこれとは話が別だろう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Aside from that case, it's usually okay to separate the sexes in this way.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その場合は別として、このやり方で男女を別にするのは通じょうもんだいありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>period</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is very <vocabulary>contemporary</vocabulary>. But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't <vocabulary>modern</vocabulary> enough to touch your hands!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I like the contemporary design.
Context 1-JP: <jp>近代的なデザインが気に入りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It’s a really contemporary building, isn’t it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>とても近代的な建物ですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think purikura is a bit too overly-modern these days.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近のプリクラはちょっと近代的になりすぎていると思う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>king</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is the <vocabulary>king</vocabulary>, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you!
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for <jp>王</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>様</jp>. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!
Context 1-EN: The king loves cooking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>王様は料理が大好きです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの王様は、とんでもなくケチなんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The king wants to have a butt-wrestling match with a sumo wrestler.
Context 3-JP: <jp>王様は、力士と尻相撲をしたがっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>文字</jp> can mean "characters?" Well make a <kanji>face</kanji> out of those characters and you've made a <vocabulary>kaomoji</vocabulary>! <jp>ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ</jp>
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for <jp>顔</jp> added to the jukugo word <jp>文字</jp> that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!
Context 1-EN: Please express your current feelings with kaomoji.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今の気持ちを顔文字で表してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I secretly read Viet's letter to Koichi, but everything was written in kaomoji.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトがコウイチにあてた手紙を内しょで読んだら、全てが顔文字でかかれていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t use kaomoji when you’re emailing a superior!
Context 3-JP: <jp>上司へのメールに顔文字を使うんじゃない！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>writing</kanji> on a <kanji>tombstone</kanji> makes up the <vocabulary>inscription</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>epitaph</vocabulary> the family members decided to put there.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who thought of the inscription for this memorial?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この慰霊碑の碑文は誰が考えたのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some <kanji>tombstone</kanji>s are used to <kanji>write down</kanji> the <kanji>thought</kanji>s of dead people. They're <vocabulary>monument</vocabulary>s. They can be really big or really small, but they have to be dedicated to somebody (usually a dead somebody).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What kind of monument is this?
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは何の記念碑ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned how <jp>折る</jp> means "to fold." Well this is what happens after that. You folded it too far and now it's starting <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>折る</jp>, so you should know this one too!
Context 1-EN: My heart breaks when you say that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そんなことを言われると、心が折れるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was carrying a heavy load on my shoulders, my shoulder bone fractured.
Context 2-JP: <jp>重い荷物をかたにかついで運んでいたら、かたの骨が折れてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Every year, our tulips snap at the roots after they bloom.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちのチューリップ、毎年花が咲いた後、根元からポッキリ折れるんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>person</kanji> you make <kanji>love</kanji> to is your <vocabulary>lover</vocabulary>. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi's lover had an attractive, slightly nasal voice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの愛人は、少し鼻にかかったみ力的な声をしていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You couldn’t even be his lover!
Context 2-JP: <jp>お前は愛人にすらなれなかったんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm ambivalent about whether a mistress is acceptable or not.
Context 3-JP: <jp>愛人の是非については、判断しかねますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you tear (<jp>てる</jp>) up a <kanji>fruit</kanji>, its life is going <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The fruit's life is about to end and you laugh, "Hahahaha (は)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...
Context 1-EN: I haven't slept for three days and I'm exhausted.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三日もねてないから、つかれ果てたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I thought, I must not die here.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こんなところで果てるわけにはいかないと思ったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The meeting continued without any sign of ending and the employees were getting fed up.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いつ果てるともなく続く会議に、社員は全員ウンザリしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Koichi's radio-controlled helicopter crashed on the ground after hovering in midair.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチのヘリコプターのラジコンは宙をまって地面にげきとつした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like the face Koichi makes when he takes bills out of his pockets and throws them into the air.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポケットから札束を取り出し、宙にバラまく時のコウイチの顔が好きだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That problem is still up in the air and nobody tries to discuss it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの問題は宙に浮いたままで、誰も議論しようとしない。</jp>

Meaning: To Know,To Understand,To Be Aware Of,To Consent,To Agree
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>心得</jp> means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. (You know it deep in your heart.)
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Does anyone know who this woman is?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このお方をどなたと心得るか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>real</kanji> <kanji>quality</kanji> of something is its <vocabulary>essence</vocabulary>, or its <vocabulary>true nature</vocabulary>. Whether it's good or bad is a different story.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This man can see the true nature of anything instantly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この男は、物事の本質を一瞬で見抜くことができる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>echo</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird <vocabulary>reverberation</vocabulary> going.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The reaction towards this article was huge.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この記事への反響はとても大きかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>渡す</jp> means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual <kanji>hand</kanji> <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary> something too!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t have the courage to hand him the present.
Context 1-JP: <jp>プレゼントを手渡す勇気はありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>become</kanji> aware of something to an <kanji>extent</kanji> you'll end up saying <vocabulary>I see</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>That's right</vocabulary>! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary>."
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for <jp>成</jp> is from <jp>成る</jp> and it keeps the <jp>る</jp> part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!
Context 1-EN: I see! I can send this letter without anyone finding out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>成程、これなら誰にも見つからずに手紙を出すことができる。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Dark,To End,To Close,To Run Out,To Be Lost
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>暮らす</jp> means "to live?" Well when you're in too much of a rush (<jp>らす</jp>) to live life to the fullest, you won't notice it start <vocabulary>to get dark</vocabulary>. You try to live day and night until it starts <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. Shine on in that darkness!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>暮らす</jp>, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!
Context 1-EN: If you don’t hurry up, it will get dark.
Context 1-JP: <jp>早くしないと、日が暮れるわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>貴重</jp> means "valuable?" Well valuable <kanji>product</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>valuables</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please look after your own valuables.
Context 1-JP: <jp>貴重品はご自身で管理して下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Grain</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>cereal</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There are five types of grains in this soup.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このスープには五種類の穀物が入っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>scream</kanji> <kanji>wake up</kanji>! at someone you can bet they're going to <vocabulary>awaken</vocabulary>. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably <vocabulary>rouse</vocabulary> them. They'll probably be mad at you though.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: At the university entrance ceremony the students were alerted to the dangers of alcohol and cults.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学の入学式で、学生たちに飲酒やカルト宗教についての注意喚起が行われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wither</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wither</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to die</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

How do you get plants to wither? You hit them with your car (か). It isn't very good for your car either, but the plants will definitely die, so problem solved!
Context 1-EN: The tree I took great pains to grow withered.
Context 1-JP: <jp>せっかく植えた木が枯れてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Grain</kanji>s are <kanji>type</kanji>s of <vocabulary>grains</vocabulary>! You thought they would be something else? Nope. Grains are pretty boring.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I try to have grains with every meal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は穀類を毎食摂るようにしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>immersed</kanji>, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's <vocabulary>to soak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned <jp>浸る</jp>, so you should know this one too.
Context 1-EN: Why are you soaking the vegetables in water?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして野菜を水に浸しているの？</jp>

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Reading Mnemonic:
This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now.

When you think of a ginkgo tree think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles but evil Mrs. Chou likes to eat eagles AND whole gingko trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND ARE STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And gingko trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo.

The other meaning is the ginkgo nuts themselves. They taste like 銀 (ぎん) naan (なん). Mm mm soft and metallic, but still not the jukugo word though. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

Context 1-JP: <jp>銀杏を食べ過ぎると中毒症状が出ます。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>地下水が地表に自然に出てきたものを、湧水といいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you do something <kanji>gradually</kanji> for a long time, when you finish it gives you that <vocabulary>FINALLY</vocabulary> feeling. It took so long and you worked so hard and you're finally done!

Context 1-EN: I was finally able to pass the starting line as a writer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>漸く作家としてのスタートラインに立つことができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>container</kanji>s your <kanji>urine</kanji> <kanji>secrete</kanji>s into are your <vocabulary>urinary organs</vocabulary>.

Context 1-JP: <jp>泌尿器の病気で入院することになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Diarrhea</kanji> that goes <kanji>below</kanji> you is still <vocabulary>diarrhea</vocabulary>, unfortunately. I hope it's going down into a toilet...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>朝から下痢が止まりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lake</kanji> <kanji>shore</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lake shore</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In summer I read in a quiet lake shore lodge.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夏は、静かな湖畔のロッジで読書をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Correct</kanji> something you thought was already <kanji>correct</kanji> by making a <vocabulary>correction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had my teeth corrected.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歯の矯正をしていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>annoy</kanji> someone who's <kanji>busy</kanji> they're still going to be <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary>. You annoying them can't change them. Though now they're probably busy AND annoyed.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I escaped from my busy daily life and came to Hawaii.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日々の煩忙から逃れ、ハワイにやって来ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Barbarian</kanji>s <kanji>go</kanji> around and commit acts of <vocabulary>barbarism</vocabulary>! What else would they do? They're barbarians!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつらはそこで蛮行を繰り返しているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Die</kanji> in the <kanji>past</kanji> and it was <vocabulary>death</vocabulary> that you suffered from!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The company president’s death was a really big shock.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長の逝去は本当に大きなショックです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>容赦</jp> can mean "forgiveness" and "mercy?" Well add <jp>なく</jp> (basically making it NOT that), and it becomes <vocabulary>relentlessly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mercilessly</vocabulary>. The exact opposite of what it was before!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji (with <jp>なく</jp> attached to it). You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Dad relentlessly beat my younger brother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は弟を容赦なく殴りつけました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>新年</jp> means "New Year?" Well when you say <kanji>humble</kanji> <kanji>congratulations</kanji> on the new year, you're really saying <vocabulary>Happy New Year!</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Happy New Year! was written on the New Year’s card.
Context 1-JP: <jp>年賀状には謹賀新年と書いてありました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You exit but you do it with かける added to it. Just think of that かける as you exiting while being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want to go out or to leave. You go out in a cocky way!

This word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train 出かける'd.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>出る</jp>, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!
Context 1-EN: Mom went out shopping at the department store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は、デパートへかいものに出かけました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Since my husband went out with kids, I can play Dragon Quest as much as I want.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おっとが子どもをつれて出かけたので、今日はドラクエ三まいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going out to the beach with my family on Sunday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日曜日は家族で海に出かけるの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: A cute fox suddenly poked its head out of the thicket.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かわいい狐が茂みからひょこっと顔を出した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something with an <kanji>ugly</kanji> <kanji>appearance</kanji> is a <vocabulary>shameful sight</vocabulary>. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They were exposed to an unimaginably shameful sight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とんだ醜態を晒してしまったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do you <kanji>hear</kanji> that is really <kanji>ugly</kanji>? A <vocabulary>scandal</vocabulary>. Scandals are the ugliest topics for gossip.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who spread this completely untrue scandal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰がこんな根も葉もない醜聞を流したんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>year</kanji>s have passed you say that <vocabulary>several years</vocabulary> have passed! You don't want to say how many years, so just say several years.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Several years passed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>数年がすぎさった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I lived in Japan until a few years ago.
Context 2-JP: <jp>数年前まで、日本に住んでいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It will take several years for that painting to be complete.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この絵が完成するには、あと数年かかります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being comfortable like you're in heaven then you have lots of optimism. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!

This is a noun in Japanese but, depending on the context, it's often translated into English as an adjective.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My older brother doesn't have a social life, but he doesn't mind much because of his optimism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>兄は人付き合いがありませんが、楽天主義だから自分ではあまり気にしていません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't think anyone is more optimistic than he is.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あいつほど楽天主義だなあと思うやつはいない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu is as optimistic as people say he is.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは評判通りの楽天主義者だね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>mixed</kanji> <kanji>blood</kanji>, some people might say you're of <vocabulary>mixed race</vocabulary>. Own it!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It's rare for animals to mix breeds with one another.
Context 1-JP: <jp>動物は、別の種が混血することはめったにありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is a mix of Japanese and American.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは日本人とアメリカ人の混血です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Apparently, one in thirty newborn Japanese babies is of mixed parentage.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本人の新生児の三十人に一人は混血だそうですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti-</kanji> something in a way that's <kanji>different</kanji> from the norm then you'll be in <vocabulary>violation</vocabulary> of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a <vocabulary>transgression</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 違 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you find yourself in violation of the law just pull out your pet eagle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.
Context 1-EN: I was caught speeding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スピード違反で捕まった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>God</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is <vocabulary>God</vocabulary>! Or the <vocabulary>gods</vocabulary>, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: Is that god still waiting for someone to come and get him?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの神様、まだおむかえを待ってるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who comes to your mind when you hear the name "guitar god."
Context 2-JP: <jp>ギターの神様と言えば、だれを思いうかべますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: That's probably just the god of mischief.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あれは多分神様のいたずらだったのだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's another verb with the kanji <jp>増</jp>! This one means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary> too! But! These are unconscious increases, whereas <jp>増やす</jp> are usually for conscious increases.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What increases with time? Your love for your mama (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!
Context 1-EN: Sugar will make it much sweeter, you know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>砂糖でさらに甘みが増しますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You go down to the harbor and speak the secret password me natto (みなと) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!
Context 1-EN: I would like to visit the port city of Veracruz.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベラクルスという港町に行ってみたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Due to heavy rain, the road to the harbor is closed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ごう雨のため、港への道は通行止めになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.
Context 3-JP: <jp>不思議な船が港に漂着した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you say something is going to <kanji>clear up</kanji>, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes it <vocabulary>clear weather</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: The weather forecast said that it will be clear tomorrow, a day after tomorrow, and two days from now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>天気予ほうでは、明日も明後日も明々後日も晴れでしょうって言ってたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The forecast says "clear weather, with clouds later on," so I don't think you need an umbrella.
Context 2-JP: <jp>予ほうは「晴れ後くもり」だし、かさはいらないんじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s a good thing it’s clear out on your birthday, eh?
Context 3-JP: <jp>折角の誕生日だし、晴れて良かったですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know?

This word can also mean to awaken but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 覚 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wizard (ざ). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.
Context 1-EN: I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この裏ワザを使うと、朝、すっきり目覚めることができます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prohibition</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to prohibit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: This is an autobiographical novel that Koichi wrote about his own forbidden love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、コウイチが自分の禁じられた恋について書いた私小説です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The doctor forbade the pregnant woman from alcohol and cigarettes.

Context 3-EN: In this room, whispering is prohibited.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この部屋では、私語を禁じる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>present time</kanji> is the time you're <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> in. You aren't <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> in any other time, because that's not how time works!
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Didn’t you actually say that a while ago?
Context 1-JP: <jp>現にさっきそう言ったじゃありませんか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>play</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>play</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>playing</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned <jp>遊ぶ</jp>. It's the same one!
Context 1-EN: Please tell me about the popular games in schools nowadays.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近学校で流行っている遊びを教えて下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>differ</kanji>s from <kanji>normal</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>abnormal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>strange</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The abnormal weather continues.
Context 1-JP: <jp>異常気象が続いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>arm</kanji> is your <vocabulary>right arm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can either be a combination of the kun'yomi readings (more common) or the on'yomi readings (pretty uncommon, and only used to talk about sports players, especially baseball). That being said, you've seen all of these readings except <jp>う</jp>. Here's a mnemonic for if you want to remember <jp>う</jp>: Your right arm got pricked by a poisonous <reading>u</reading>ni (<jp>う</jp>), and it has to be amputated. Hope you're not right-handed!
Context 1-EN: I think that’s supposed to be a dragon tattoo on that guy’s right arm.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奴の右腕には、龍のタトゥーがあるハズだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>hand</kanji>'s <kanji>neck</kanji> is your <vocabulary>wrist</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
Context 1-EN: I fell and twisted my wrist.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ころんで手首をひねった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hot oil splashed on my wrist and I got burned.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あぶらが手首にはねてヤケドしてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My twin sister has a mole on her wrist.
Context 3-JP: <jp>双子の妹には、手首にホクロがあるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Please don’t knock on the door.
Context 1-JP: <jp>戸をたたかないでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My cat likes scratching the door.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちのねこは戸をカリカリするのがすきです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This door opens and closes hard.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この戸は立てつけがわるい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>place</kanji> you live <kanji>near</kanji> is your <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on <jp>しょ</jp> making it <jp>じょ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Are the neighbors quiet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>近所の人はしずかですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Many chic shops are gathering in the neighborhood of the Tofugu office.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのオフィスの近所には、おしゃれなお店が多く集まっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is a laundromat in the neighborhood.
Context 3-JP: <jp>近所にコインランドリーがあるわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>生物</jp> means "living things?" Well when you <kanji>study</kanji> living things you're studying <vocabulary>biology</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Two of my favorite subjects are biology and biochemistry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの一番すきな科目は生物学と生化学です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Ms. Kawada's older brother is a scholar who specializes in biology.
Context 2-JP: <jp>川田さんのお兄さんは生物学をせんもんとする学者さんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you want to become a designer, you should also study biology.
Context 3-JP: <jp>デザイナーになりたいなら、生物学も学んだ方がいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>abilities</kanji> you <kanji>origin</kanji>ally start out with are <vocabulary>instinct</vocabulary>s. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Animals have an instinctive fear of fire, but Koichi was an exception.
Context 1-JP: <jp>動物は本能的に火をおそれるが、コウイチは例外だった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I always try to rely on my innate instincts as much as possible.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつも、生まれもった本能のおももくままにできるだけしたがうようにしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The bear sensed danger with its animal instincts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>熊は、動物の本能で危険を察知した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: If you wash it with hot water, you might be able to remove it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お湯であらってみたら、落ちるかもしれないよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After going number two, Koichi washes his hands with hot water and soap.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは大きい方をした後、お湯と石けんで手をあらいます。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>お湯を沸かしてくれないか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Yesterday</kanji>'s <kanji>year</kanji> was actually <vocabulary>last year</vocabulary>. Today must be New Years then!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This 24-hour supermarket was opened last year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この二十四時間スーパーは、昨年オープンしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I went on a trip to Guam last year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨年は旅行でグアムに行きました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Last year, my doctor told me that I have a high level of triglycerides.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨年、医者から中性しぼうのあたいが高いと言われちゃったんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji> and <kanji>calculate</kanji>? Why, that's just <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for <jp>割</jp> and the on'yomi for <jp>算</jp>. And the <jp>さん</jp> reading is rendaku'd into <jp>ざん</jp>. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
Context 1-EN: I made a mistake on such a simple division problem.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな簡単な割り算の問題を間違えちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You want to <kanji>transport</kanji> something by <kanji>send</kanji>ing it? Well that's <vocabulary>transportation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please tell me the transportation cost.
Context 1-JP: <jp>輸送コストを教えて下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you try to <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, but instead you feel the urge to <kanji>hang</kanji> your teacher, you know you're doing <vocabulary>multiplication</vocabulary>. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!
Reading Mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for <jp>掛</jp> and the on'yomi for <jp>算</jp>. And the <jp>さん</jp> reading is rendaku'd into <jp>ざん</jp>. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
Context 1-EN: There’s a multiplication test in cram school tomorrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日、塾で掛け算のテストがあるんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Make A Mistake,To Confuse,To Mistake
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>間違い</jp> means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: It's read the same as <jp>間違い</jp>! Nice and easy!
Context 1-EN: Making a mistake on such a simple question is so frustrating.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな簡単な問題を間違えるなんて、悔しいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>search</kanji> <kanji>search</kanji> is a more intense <vocabulary>search</vocabulary>, like the ones for a missing person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The police are continuing to work on the investigation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察は捜索活動を続けています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji>, just means <vocabulary>after this</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>from now on</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "After this you need to be more careful so this doesn't happen again." "Yes, teacher. I'll be more careful from now on."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「以後、このようなことがないように、気をつけるんだぞ。」「はい、先生。以後、もっと気をつけます。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet hasn't been heard of since October 29—Tofugu Day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>10月29日のトーフグの日以後、ビエトは行方をくらましているんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After that, the writer stopped drinking alcohol, not even a single drop.
Context 3-JP: <jp>それ以後、その作家は酒を一滴も飲まなくなった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>price</kanji> <kanji>tag</kanji> is... a <vocabulary>price tag</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 値 in the vocabulary word 値(ね), earlier in this level. You learned the reading for 札 in the vocabulary 札(ふだ). Put them together and you have ねふだ.
Context 1-EN: This item doesn't have a price tag.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この品物には、値札シールがありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The king always buys stuff without looking at the price tags and the queen gets angry at him.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王様は、いつも値札を見ずに買い物をして、女王様に怒られます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After checking the price tag, I decided not to buy it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>値札を確かめた後に、買うのを止めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>luggage</kanji> <kanji>tag</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> you put on luggage. It's also a <vocabulary>label</vocabulary> you can put on a package before you send it, like a <vocabulary>shipping label</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for a tag to put on my suitcase.
Context 1-JP: <jp>旅行かばんに付ける荷札をさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please tell me how to write a package label.
Context 2-JP: <jp>荷札の書き方を教えてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The label is coming off from the parcel.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その小包、荷札が剥がれてるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wash</kanji> <kanji>wash</kanji> <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary> your clothes. You wash wash your laundry. Hmm wash wash sounds like the sound my laundry machine makes when it's washing my underpants.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I washed my sweater in hot water and it shrunk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>セーターをお湯で洗濯したら縮んでしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I married him because he said he likes doing laundry, but he still hasn't even done it once.
Context 2-JP: <jp>洗濯が好きだと言っていたから結婚したのに、今まで一度も洗濯をしてくれたことがありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Is my white shirt in the wash?" "Oh, that one had lipstick on it, so I took it to the cleaners."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「俺のワイシャツ、今洗濯してる？」「ああ、それなら口紅が付いていたので洗濯屋さんに出しておいたわよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The person who <kanji>throw</kanji>s with their <kanji>hand</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pitcher</vocabulary> in a baseball game. Other games don't involve throwing with your hand, they've got kicking with feet. So when you picture a hand throwing, picture your favorite pitcher!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 手 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

To be a good pitcher, all you have to do is put the ball into the chute (しゅ). Pitchers don't actually throw the ball. There is an invisible pitching chute right on the mound. You slide the ball into the chute and off it goes!
Context 1-EN: How much is the doll of the pitcher, Darvish?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのダルビッシュ投手の人形はいくらですか？</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>二丁目には、田中投手が住んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Who do you think today's starting pitcher will be?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日の先発投手は誰になると思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know <jp>札</jp> means "amulet" but this is a special <kanji>honorable</kanji> <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary>. It's a talisman.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>御</jp> is <jp>お</jp> because <jp>ふだ</jp> uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.
Context 1-EN: Why did you put the talisman here?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてここに御札をはっているんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is an amulet that I got from the shrine in my hometown.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは、地元の神社でもらった御札です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are there talismans in English-speaking countries, too?
Context 3-JP: <jp>英語圏の国にも、御札ってあるんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>transmit</kanji> the story of someone's life, you have to <kanji>write down</kanji> all of it in a <vocabulary>biography</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The pitcher's life story was interesting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この投手の伝記、おも白かったよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The stuff that was written in the writer's biography was very surprising.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その作家の伝記に書かれていたことは、とても意外だった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Well, I think I might feel like this because I was influenced by a biography I read recently.
Context 3-JP: <jp>まあ、そう思うのは、最近読んだ伝記の影響かもしれません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you put something <kanji>spicy</kanji> in your <kanji>mouth</kanji> you'll end up with a <vocabulary>spicy taste</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>dry taste</vocabulary> in there. Spice sucks up all your mouth moistness.
Reading Mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi readings together. You should have learned them both by now.
Context 1-EN: Which curry do you usually buy: mild, medium-hot, or spicy?
Context 1-JP: <jp>カレーはいつも、甘口、中辛、辛口、どれを買いますか？</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>庄司さんは、辛口の酒が好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Everyone gave harsh comments, but I actually like this movie.
Context 3-JP: <jp>みんなは辛口コメントだったけど、私はこの映画好きだな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Far</kanji> <kanji>feet</kanji> are feet that have gone on long <vocabulary>excursions</vocabulary>. These feet have been on some <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary>s, man. They've seen some things.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We went on a school trip to the zoo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校の遠足で、動物園に行きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When spring comes, let's go on an outing to the ocean.
Context 2-JP: <jp>春になったら、海に遠足しようよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We went on an excursion to Hanshin Koshien Stadium to watch a baseball game and root for the Hanshin Tigers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>遠足で阪神甲子園球場に野球観戦に行って、阪神タイガースを応援しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. A <kanji>lie</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lie</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned with reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: It's not true, is it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>嘘ですよね？</jp>
Context 2-EN: My motto is, "I will not tell a lie."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「嘘をつかない」は私のモットーです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Saying you won 100 million yen in the lottery sounds like a lie, I can't believe that!
Context 3-JP: <jp>宝くじで1億円当たったなんて、嘘の話みたいで信じられない！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well こういち is still in your throat and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "No Do- (のど)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...
Context 1-EN: Cats purr with their throats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>猫は、喉でゴロゴロという音を出します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Your throat's gotten slimmer lately, hasn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近、喉がやせたんじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a sore throat. Can you sing on my behalf?
Context 3-JP: <jp>喉が痛いので、私の代わりに歌ってくれませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Throat</kanji> <kanji>candy</kanji> is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a <vocabulary>cough drop</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>throat lozenge</vocabulary>. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: I wish mayonnaise flavored cough drops existed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マヨネーズ味の喉飴があったら良いのになあ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you happen to have a throat lozenge?
Context 3-EN: Don't you think cough drops taste like the science room?
Context 3-JP: <jp>喉飴って理科室みたいな味がすると思わない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>knee</kanji>'s <kanji>head</kanji> is the <vocabulary>kneecap</vocabulary>. It's also called the <vocabulary>patella</vocabulary>, if you want to get fancy and talk about bone names.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're walking around in your mom's house, minding your own business, when you slam your kneecap right into that gargoyle she loves (がしら). It hurts so bad, you can't even think out that phrase and instead you shout out, "GA SHE RA" and fall to the floor, clutching your searing kneecap (which has probably broken in half).
Context 1-EN: The hair on my kneecap bothers me so much that I can hardly even sleep.
Context 1-JP: <jp>膝頭の毛が気になって眠れることすらできない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: While Koichi was sleeping, I drew eyes on his kneecaps.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチが寝ている間に、膝頭に目を書いた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Apparently, Apple is going to start developing kneecap recognition.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今年アップル社は、膝頭認証の開発を始めるらしい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wet</kanji> or <kanji>damp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: It's good to wet your hair before shampooing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>髪をよく濡らしてから、シャンプーをするといいですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This USB is important, so please be careful not to get it wet with coffee or water.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大事なUSBなので、コーヒーや水で濡らさないで下さいね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since I was dumped by my senpai, I've been soaking my pillow with tears.
Context 3-JP: <jp>先輩にフラれてから、毎日涙で枕を濡らしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eyebrow's</kanji> <kanji>hair</kanji> is the individual <vocabulary>eyebrow</vocabulary> hair that makes them up.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: Even though I just shaved my eyebrows three hours ago, I'm already starting to get a unibrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三時間前に眉毛をそったばかりなのに、もう眉毛がつながりそうだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I dyed my eyebrows to match my dress.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ドレスの色に合わせて、眉毛を染めたの。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It takes me a couple hours to draw my eyebrows on every morning.
Context 3-JP: <jp>眉毛を書くのに毎朝二時間くらいかかる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Envy</kanji> consumes your <kanji>hope</kanji> turning it all to <vocabulary>envy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jealousy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: Hachi is a target of jealousy in the dog world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ハチは、犬界での羨望の的だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: He was eating such delicious-looking curry bread that he attracted envious stares.
Context 2-JP: <jp>彼は、あまりにも美味しそうなカレーパンを食べていたため羨望の視線を浴びた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I couldn't ignore my envious feelings toward Gordon and I decided to pursue my career in cuisine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ゴードンへの羨望の気持ちが抑えきれず、料理の道へ進みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one loaf of bread</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!
Context 1-EN: Loaves of bread are often sold in slices of six or eight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一斤のパンは6枚切りか8枚切りで売られていることが多い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I need to survive on only one loaf of bread until payday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>たった一斤のパンで給料日までを生き延びなければいけない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can live off of a loaf of bread and some Nutella.
Context 3-JP: <jp>食パン一斤と、ニュテラがあれば生きていけるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>s are counting <vocabulary>two loaves of bread</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you buy two loaves of bread it will be 100 yen cheaper.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二斤買えば100円もお得です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though I baked two loaves of bread, we finished it all.
Context 2-JP: <jp>パンを二斤も焼いたのに、すぐに食べ切ってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you think we can finish these two loaves of bread even though they're expiring the day after tomorrow?
Context 3-JP: <jp>賞味期限が明後日だけど、二斤も食べきれるかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fear</kanji> mixed with <kanji>confusion</kanji> creates <vocabulary>panic</vocabulary>! You get a <vocabulary>scare</vocabulary> so bad, you're fearful and you don't know what to do.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: The village was consumed with panic on the day I wasn't there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私が留守だった日、村は恐慌に包まれた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wasn't expecting to experience two economic scares in my lifetime.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人生で二度もの経済恐慌を経験するとは思っていなかったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The entire country flew into a panic.
Context 3-JP: <jp>国全体が恐慌状態に陥った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Half</kanji> <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s is just another name for <vocabulary>short sleeves</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <jp>半</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>袖</jp>. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.
Context 1-EN: Aren't you cold in a short sleeve top?
Context 1-JP: <jp>半袖で寒くない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: After reading Kon Mari's book, I only own one short sleeve shirt.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コンマリの本を読んでから、半袖のシャツは一枚しか持っていない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This year's trending fashion is short sleeve leather jackets.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今年のファッショントレンドは半袖の革ジャンです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s are <vocabulary>long sleeves</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: Should I wear a long sleeve top today?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、長袖着ていった方がいいかな？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you help me shop for some long sleeve hoodies?
Context 2-JP: <jp>長袖のパーカーを買いに行くのに、付き合ってくれない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Sometimes my boyfriend wears long sleeves in summer in order to hide his tattoos.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の彼氏は、タトゥー隠すため夏でも長袖を着ることがある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji means strangle and this vocab is the verb version of that: to strangle.

There is another word, 絞る which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has める sticking out of it. Imagine that in the mail める you get a letter that says "I'm going to strangle you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling.
Reading Mnemonic: The thing that is threatening <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you is actually a <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.
Context 1-EN: My younger brother was strangled by a sheep.
Context 1-JP: <jp>弟は羊に首を絞められた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something really <kanji>terrible</kanji> causing mass <kanji>extinction</kanji> will be <vocabulary>extremely gruesome</vocabulary>. It will also probably be <vocabulary>extremely violent</vocabulary>, so don't look.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: The murder scene was extremely gruesome.
Context 1-JP: <jp>殺人現場は凄絶だった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My grandmother experienced a war and lived in an extremely fierce era.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の祖母は戦争を経験し、凄絶な時代を生きました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I feel like I just saw the extreme violence of this world with my own eyes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>たった今、世界の凄絶さを目にした気がした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chat</kanji> or <kanji>talk</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to chat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.
Context 1-EN: Let's have a little chat later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あとでちょっと喋ろうよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That fairy is really talkative, don't you think?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの妖精は本当によく喋るよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>supernatural</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> flutters up to you. It's a <vocabulary>fairy</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There is a fairy living inside this tulip.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このチューリップの花の中には妖精が住んでいるんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Masaru, I didn't know you had relatives that were fairies.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まさる君の親戚に妖精がいるなんて、知らなかったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This piece of information is particularly useful for fairies.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この情報は、特に妖精にとって役立つものです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is noisy and picky, so the adjective version is also noisy and picky.

This type of noisy can be just about being noisy, like a group of turkeys. It can also be a ""picky"" sort of noisy, when someone is being particular in a vocal sort of way.
Reading Mnemonic: My <vocabulary>noisy</vocabulary> mom has earned the nickname <reading>yak-a-Ma</reading> (<jp>やかま</jp>). "Yakka yakka yakka," is what my mom says about my life choices.
Context 1-EN: "Ahh, so loud. Shut up!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ああ、喧しい！だまれ！」</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's so noisy I can't focus on WaniKani.
Context 2-JP: <jp>喧しくてワニカニに集中できない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That dude bugs me with so many Yokai related questions, he's so annoying.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あいつは妖怪について喧しく質問してくるのでうざい。</jp>

Meaning: To Roll Something,To Turn Something Over
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means revolve, and the verb version is when you make something revolve. You roll it. That's why this verb is to roll something.

This is a transitive verb. That means you roll something else, like a ball. Or, if you're a dung beetle, poop. 💩 Not to be confused with 転がる, which is intransitive, like so many verbs ending in がる.
Reading Mnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned 転がる, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case:

When you try to roll something, the outside bits may be moving, but its core (ころ) stays still. Picture yourself making the earth roll across the floor. The outside parts where the people live are spinning round and round, but the earth's core is in exactly the same place.
Context 1-EN: I rolled a can of juice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カンジュースを転がした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The baby likes pushing the doll to turn it over.
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんは人形をおして転がすのが好きだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Dung beetles are called “poop rollers” because they roll poop.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Dung beetleは、フンを転がすことから「フンコロガシ」と言います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to spill or to fall out.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.
Context 1-EN: At the moment I farted, a teardrop fell out of my eyes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おならをした瞬間、目から涙が零れた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Someone spilled tea on the couch! Who's the guilty one?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ソファに紅茶が零れてるんだけど！誰が犯人だ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: A beautiful melody spilled out from the window.
Context 3-JP: <jp>窓から美しいメロディが零れてきた。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Cooked,To Be Boiled,To Be Done Cooking
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be boiled</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be done cooking</vocabulary>. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.
Context 1-EN: Is the rice done cooking?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご飯、炊けた？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today's dinner is curry spaghetti, not curry rice. I forgot to put the plug in, so the rice isn't cooked.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今晩はカレーライスじゃなくてカレースパゲッティ。コンセントを差し忘れて、ご飯が炊けてなかったんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It's only five minutes left until the daikon gets cooked.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大根が炊けるまであと五分やで。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

You already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means to be boiled or to be cooked.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!
Context 1-EN: Are the beans cooked well?
Context 1-JP: <jp>豆、ちゃんと煮えてる？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Well, it's about time that the potatoes should be cooked through.
Context 2-JP: <jp>さて、そろそろジャガ芋が煮えるころだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There was a mysterious soup gurgling and boiling in the pot.
Context 3-JP: <jp>鍋の中には怪しげなスープがグツグツと煮えていた。</jp>
